loans.name: Sapnah

texts.en:
Sapnah is an MBK member who requested a second loan of $100. Sapnah owns several businesses such as selling deep-fried-snacks and Tekwan (traditional food from Palembang) and raising chickens. Before joining MBK, Sapnah sold shoes on credit to her customers. From her fried-snacks and Tekwan business she can earn IDR 50,000 with a profit of IDR 10,000 daily. During dry season she switches to selling gado-gado or karedok (Indonesian style salads)

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her food stall and to raise chickens

loans.name: Matalena

texts.en: A Matalena V. was born on the 17th of October 1965.  She has six children. Her small business project is BANANA FARM.  She said, this is a good income for her family not only that but it really helps her husband who is working in order to get extra money for their family. Matalena is very happy about her project that she is working on it gives her time to get away from her family and exercise.  Matalena works from eight o’clock in the morning and finished at five in the evening.  Matalena goes to town to sell her baskets of banana to the market.  She earns more than hundred tala a day from her selling.  She is confident of how to run her business and she has her family to give her a hand in order for her make things easier.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides, farm implements

loans.name: Tafale

texts.en: Tafale is a strong and a hard working woman.  Her business is a Retail shop.   Tafale was born on the 28th of July 1968.  She gave birth to seven children, four are in school and three are staying home.  Tafale comes from a family of eleven members.  Tafale has a strong heart for running her business and she has no doubt at all. She’s confident in running her business by herself.  Tafale's kids also help her if she’s not available.  Tafale provides the best service to her customers by ordering good quality products to sell at her shop.  Tafale's aim is to extend her shop into a wholesale business.  Tafale is capable of how to handle customer of what they want.  She uses her loan to buy more products to fill empty shelves and to buy iron roofing,paints to renovate her shop to attract  more customers.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for the retail shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Salepou

texts.en:
Mrs Salepou is a hard working woman.  She works everyday from the morning till the evening trying to maintain the good condition of her farm.  She struggles for so many years trying to earn money to help her family, but now she has become a very successful woman. This business is really helping her and her family to meet their needs.  She is confident in running her business by herself.  She uses her loan to buy equipment to help her run her taro farm.  She is happy about the flow of her business everyday.  She has succeeded in her business through out the time she began doing it. She has variety of products such as taro, banana, peas, yams that grow on the farm.
Her family have given her the support of running her business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Aiga

texts.en: Aiga A. is one of most talented woman in weaving fans by using the Samoan tree called lau fala (pandana). She is from the village of Malie.  She is forty years of age and has seven children.  She loves weaving fans.  She said "weaving fan is another good way to earn money," because many tourists that come to Samoa to explore the beauty of the island, they are interested in buying fans because of the hot weather. She has no doubt of running her business, she’s confident in doing everything.  She earns more than sixty dollars a day from her selling samoan fans.  She has a strong feeling that she will enlarge her business in the near future.  She will use her loan to buy some more plants, in order for her to weave more fans, and also to buy paints to make the fans colorful and attractive.  Her business is going pretty well each day and there are more customers coming to buy stuff from her. She sells her fans at the Flea market,village shops,and also in front of some of the shops at town.  She is very delightful of the handicrafts business that she’s doing it at the moment, and it really helps her to satisfy family needs.

loans.use: To purchase weaving materials and equipment

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Vai

texts.en: Vai A. S. is a hard working person.  Vai goes to her farm everyday to check and get goods to sell at the market.  Vai also uses loan to buy knives, spades to do her job at her plantation.  Vai has different varieties of products at her plantation such as taro, banana, yams, breadfruit, Samoan coco (for tea) and many more. Vai also gets help from her family in running the business.  Vai is so happy to work on her farm, as this is the source of income she gets to help out with the family daily needs.

loans.use: To purchase farm equipment, fertilizers. pesticides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mere

texts.en: Mrs. Mere V. talent is, ELEI.  She’s thirty-one years of age and married to Mr. V. from the village of Levi.  Mere elei's more than ten materials a day.  She elei's, print names design pictures on ielavalava and shirts.  During my project check Mere is very happy at what she’s doing.  She’s thankful to God for the gift that he gave to her to help fulfill the needs of her family.  Her business project has improved in many ways, x-rays papers provide by her friends, toothbrush, sponge,  paints and most of all her family support.  Mere believes that her business is doing fine because of the growth of the number of her customers.  She sells some of her stuff at her home, she also delivers some to the shops around the island.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, paints, stencils and other materials for the business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Lipine

texts.en: Lipine M. is a well-known businesswoman.  She works hard in order for her to help and satisfy her family needs.  She’s born on the 20th April 1938.  She has nine children, five are married and three are not married.  Lipine comes from a family of six people.  She’s a hard working person due to her income earns from each day.  She earns $150 tala a day from selling her products at the market, small retailer and at her residence.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizers, pesticides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Suluama

texts.en:
Suluama lives in the village of Faleasiu, where she was born and raised, with her husband and five children, four of which are in school and one is a one year-old baby.

She has always dreamed of having a business of her own, and her dream has now come true with the help of the SPBDF.  She believes that her business will grow in the future by satisfying her customers by providing them with the best service and products.

Suluama is assisted by her husband and two brothers who help her run business by planting cabbages, tomatoes and pumpkins, and by weeding and picking up small stones.

She is applying for a loan of $900 in order to purchase piglets and repair their pigpens.

loans.use: To purchase additional piglets, and improve the pigpens

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Dinna

texts.en: A mother of one 20-year-old, Dinna loves to show off her talent of sewing and designing. As a result, she opened up a sewing business from her family house at Faleula fou to help earn enough to put her child through school and build a stable future for herself. Her designs include the modern aspects of a puletasi Samoa’s traditional wear. Because of this skill Dinna’s designs are in high demand.

loans.use: to purchase materials and equipment to build permanent housing for her business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Pelelina

texts.en: Peleina O. was born on the 20th of August 1973.  She has eight children, five are in school, and three are staying home.  Peleina's husband and her three brothers are helping her out to clean her vegetable garden.  She has done a great job by improving her business in buying equipment from her loan.  Peleina has given all her effort in doing her business.  She said running this business is not an easy task for her but this business has given the challenge of how to do things that she didn’t do before. Peleina said she received hundred and fifty money from her goods she sold. Peleina is using the money to do what her family wants and especially her children’s fees.  Her business has improved by growing more vegetables such as cabbages, tomatoes and more.  She sells her goods at the market, shops in her village and also in her own residence.  She has a strong belief that she will become a better businesswoman in the future.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables seeds, fertilizers, pesticides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Seneuefa

texts.en: Seneuefa T. is a hard working woman of fifty -three (53) years of age who has seven children.  All of her children completed school and three of them are working and four are at home.  She has a strong heart believing that her business is going well.   Her loan would be used to enlarge her shop to meet her customer’s need.  One of her daughter's is helping her in shop keeping if she is tired and not available during the day. She is getting more customers because she opens her shop through out the whole day right up from six thirty in the morning until nine thirty at night.  Her sales count per day is $180.00.  Her husband also help her to organize the products on the shelves. Seneuefa’s motto is, struggle leads to a happy end, and that’s why she’s doing fine with her business.

loans.use: To purchase more goods, and renovate the shop building

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: 58 year old Elisapeta M. is a mother of eight from Faleula fou who has great talent in elei printing long before joining SPBD but because there was no way to finance a business, Elisapeta never made use of her talents until the programme financed it. Elei printing is a form of printing created and designed on fabric by using colour paints. The designs are usually traditional arts but are very much liked by tourists and used on wrap a rounds and sun dresses. Elei printing is the only source of income for the family which is why Elisapeta wants to expand her business to earn enough to develop the status of her family and help fund her children’s school fees.

loans.use: Purchase rolls of fabrics

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina I. is a middle-aged woman who works hard to develop her family. She’s forty-six years old and a mother of four children.  Tina really has the skills for running a small business.  She started off with a canteen selling buns, donuts, ice-cake and banana chips at her village school.  “It is really a hard job to do everyday” Tina says that she’s being doing it almost two years now. She’s running her business project and she said she can do better than that.  Her dreams came true is when she used her loan to run the daily canteen at her village school into a well organized new shop.  Tina just opened her shop a couple of months ago and she said her sales each day are fine and she has a strong feeling that she is going to enlarge her shop in the near future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for the shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Epenesa

texts.en: Elei printing is a common business in Samoa that is in high demand with overseas and locals alike. Elei is the art of drawing patterns on a plate and then cutting it into shapes. In Samoa, it is usually in the patterns of traditional Samoan war weapons or national flower, herbs and flowers found on the island. It is then attached to the fabric and painted over with different colours. Epenesa sells her elei materials to people in her village, overseas, at the local market and stores that order her designs.

loans.use: To purchase a dozen paints for printing and designing patterns on the fabrics

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mativa

texts.en: Mativa S. is a young talented woman of thirty-two years of age.   She is a woman who loves to do what she is doing.  She spends most of her time going to her plantation to weed, clean and plant taro, banana, breadfruit and much more.  Mativa is earning one hundred and fifty a day from her goods that she sells at the market.  She believes in herself and that having her business really helps her out through her church stuff and her family needs.  The growth of her product is good to sell to the people.  She has no doubt of what to sell because she has different kinds of goods at her plantation to sell.  Mativa wants to maintain the good condition of her plantation by using her loan to buy more equipments (e.g.) spade, knives, etc.

loans.use: To purchase  fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides and farm implements

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Eseta

texts.en: Eseta has been running her restaurant for the past five years catering to Yazaki Eds Samoa employees. The restaurant caters snacks, Chinese cakes, and other affordable snacks which are all produced and cooked by Eseta. Eseta’s restaurant is likely to succeed because she is catering to one of the biggest companies with the highest number of employees. She also knows what her customers want and can afford which is one of the reasons why it is expanding. Eseta also caters to local schools. It is her enthusiasm, hard work, and dedication into reaching her dream that has taken her this far to five years in the restaurant business.

loans.use: finance equipment to further expand the Food Stall

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ilo

texts.en: Ilo I. is a well-known woman in her village and she believes in herself and in what she is doing.  Ilo struggled for a long time due to financial stuff.  But I. has achieved one of her goals to become a successful businesswoman.  I. works everyday on her plantation to maintain its good condition.  She is very happy because she does not worry about anything; she has her own business to run and earns money for herself.  Ilo I. receives more than a hundred tala a day from her merchandise she sells to the market. Ilo uses her loan to buy equipment to help her to do her work easier.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers, pesticides, fungicides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Luisa

texts.en: Luisa I. is from the village of Fasitoo-uta.  She was born on the 13th August 1971. Her business project is sewing her family's clothes and other people's.  She is very happy of her talents because it helps her to develop her family.  She is a woman of so many talents but she likes sewing the most.  I. said she could sew more than twenty clothes a day plus her own materials to sell.  She believes that her project is very unique.   She has no doubt of doing it.  I. is using her loan to help her buy tools to fix her sewing machine when it becomes damaged.   She believes that she will become a better businesswoman in future.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics, threads, and additional tools for sewing

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Faleao

texts.en: Not many people have the talent in using natural resources to make cricket balls. And it is not every ones talent in Samoa but, Faleao, since she was a child has always been fascinated by the cricket ball and the raw materials from the forest that are used to make them in Samoa. In addition, when it was her turn to be taught the traditional family secrets she put all her efforts and time into producing this solid product.  She is likely to succeed because Faleao has the potential to make it into the overseas market. Although she caters to local markets, the only chance she has of displaying her products overseas is through people that come to Samoa buying her product. Her products are used in American Samoa, the United States of America in Samoan communities, Australia and New Zealand. She dreams of building a solid foundation to house her products one day.

loans.use: buy materials for expanding her business.

loans.name: Toalua

texts.en: Toalua of Vaitele-m tai is a hard working lady and she knows that she cannot sit back and rely on her family members to support her. With the great assistance given to her by the SPBD she is now running her own business to support herself and her whole family. Every day is vital to Toalua so she has her barbecue stand running on everyday of the week. She earns three hundred tala daily and uses half of it for her shopping, fifty tala is used for family necessities and uses the hundred that is left for her loan repayments and for her personal savings.

loans.use: To purchase stand, mutton flaps, turkey tail, chicken,  soy sauce, plastic plates,   cements,  and timber.

loans.name: Fia

texts.en: Fia is a 56 year old mother who shouldn’t be working anymore but because she thinks that she hasn’t given enough for her family and children, she decided to set up a business that would help develop the standard of her family. Everyday, she looks at ways to improve and cater good quality seafood to her customers and it is her hard work and determination that has brought her this far.

loans.use: Purchase fishing equipment to improve the standard of the business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Leleo

texts.en: Vegetables are really important in our daily lives and that is what Leleo M. belives in. She grows different varieties of vegetables like pumpkins, cabbages, cucumbers and tomatoes to name a few. A determined and hard working woman  most of her times is spent in selling her produce at the market. Leleo earns eighty-tala everyday of the week.  However, bad weather is a constraint for Leleo’s small business sometimes. Nevertheless she is always willing to overcome these problems and she is confident that her son who has a small business of his own can assist her whenever she is in need.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, rage, cabbages, cucumber, pumpkin (seeds), knives, cement, sand, and timber.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Fipe

texts.en: 61-year-old Fipe believes in hard work and perseverance as the root to success. A married woman who enjoys engaging herself in active duties decided to put her skills into good use with setting up a business in this area. Fipe sells her catch to people in her village and those living in Apia. Because of her determination and perseverance, her business has been able to stand the demand and competition from other fishing businesses. Fipe’s catch includes Samoan delicacies such as fish, eels, crabs and seaweed.

loans.use: to purchase fishing materials

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Fono

texts.en: Unlike other farmers who only specialize in growing only one specific root crop or vegetable, Fono believes in multi-cropping. She grows a range of them from root crops to vegetables and fruits like mangos, cucumbers and cocoa for example. Despite not having any children to help, her extended family provides labor to assist her in growing and selling her produce. Fono’s normal income is one hundred tala in a  day depending on the sales. The money is used to expand her small businesss and for family commitments as this is the family’s main source of income. She is very thankful for the support from SPBD that has made all these things possible for her and her family.

loans.use: To purchase Tiapula, fertilizer, piki, banana, cabbages(seeds)(HI)=cement, iron roof.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Folole

texts.en: A plantation is a common source of income in Samoa. There are hundreds of families that have survived the daily expenses on crops produced on their plantations. Although it is a common source of income Folole insists that her business is likely to succeed because she has a way with knowing what is good and not good for her crops. In Samoa, it is not necessarily the cheaper crops that are sold but the biggest. Folole works six days a week on expanding her plantation and working on ways to better the quality of her crops.

loans.use: to purchase equipment for improving crops fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia a mother of six and is reliant on her barbeque stand to care for her children’s needs, particularly in paying for their education. The stand operates from Wednesday to Friday as she believes these are the days that attract a lot of the customers. She is also lucky to have a spot in town for her to sell her barbeque in which roughly she  earns a profit of two hundred tala on each of these days. Fortunately for her, the other two children work and they lessen her burden as she knows that from what she earns she is able to pay back her loan.  At the same time, she is certain that her family is financially secure and that there is always an alternate solution if they come across any financial problems in running her stand and most of all in paying back the amount she owes SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase BBQ stand, mutton flaps, chicken, turkey tail, pepper,  fork, pot, plastic plates, foil, soy sauce, garlic pepper, tomato sauce (ED) school fees, uniform,

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Taua

texts.en: Taua started her own flea market stand and as time went by she decided that she wanted to expand her career to do something else to coincide with her present business. She is grateful to SPBD for giving her the financing to start working on her vegetable plots. From it she then earns another extra one hundred and twenty daily which is higher than what she usually gets from her flea market stand. Now her husband who is her co-partner and herself make a profit of six hundred tala from both her small businesses in a week. Taua is very impressed with the outcome and she is always ready to make weekly payments of her loan.

loans.use: To purchase materials, gel, sandals, spray, glass, bags, hats, tanoa, fertilizer, knives, cabbage(seeds),	(HI)=cement,  and timber.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ausage

texts.en: Now most people have no time to cook home made food and are up and about looking for fast food. There is no place further to look than Ausage’s stall in the marketplace where most of us go for an affordable meal. Her loan from SPBD helped in improving her business in terms of buying cooking utensils, supplying the ingredients for the different dishes like fresh fish, mutton flaps and other meat products. Ausage earns one hundred and fifty tala per day. She is assisted by her husband so there is no need to hire extra workers as they can manage on there own but they also manage money wisely in minimizing expenses.

loans.use: To purchase stove, pots, plates, mutton flaps, turkey tail, chicken, banana, soy sauce, etc.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Lise

texts.en: Lise is a talented mother who decided to put her fishing skills to good use by starting a fishing business to cater to people from her village. She built a business with help from the South Pacific Business Development. However, Lise wants to expand and better develop her fishing tools to catch bigger fish and to go out for longer periods to fish. She has been in this line of business since she started with SPBD. A mother of four her business is the sole bread winner for her family as her husband is unemployed.

loans.use: Fishing nets

loans.name: Maluimaauga

texts.en:
Maluimaauga (Malu) is married and has three children.

She joined the SPBDF program in 2004, and since then has borrowed four times to expand and improve her plantation and start an ice-cake business, which are the primary sources of income for her family.

Every day she travels to the market to sell her bananas and coconuts from her plantation and ice-cake business.

Malu is now applying for her 5th loan to allow her to expand her plantation in order to enable her to export produce to New Zealand.

loans.use: Improve her Plantation to enable her to export produce to New Zealand.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Susitina

texts.en:
The market in Fugalei is a busy place every day, and every day you can count on seeing Susitana in her canteen stall.  She specializes in hot breakfast items such as pancakes, toast, eggs, hot dogs and coffee and tea - all sold at reasonable prices.

Susitana is a very hard worker and has six dependents.  She feels is thankful for the loans that she has received in the past, and feels obligated to repay the kind people who helped her start her business.  

She earns approximately 120 tala per week and is applying for another loan to allow her to purchase additional food supplies, building materials and equipment to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase a gas stove, building materials and food supplies to expand her business.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mele

texts.en:
Mele is a mother of two who was never able to complete her education and as a result, her elei printing and design business is the only source of income for her and her family.  Although her husband works, his income is very low.  Her elei business has enabled the family to afford some of the necessities of life that they were unable to afford before.

Elei printing takes a great deal of skill, as well as the knowing what the tastes of tourists and locals are.  Elei printing is a modern art that uses  tapa cloth and is one of Samoa's treasured and historical products.

Mele is applying for a loan of $650 from SPBDF to purchase additional materials to allow her to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase materials such as fabric and paints

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Suifilifilia

texts.en:
Suifilifili operates a food stall three days a week in her local open air market.  She prepares and sells hot food items such as fried mutton flaps, turkey tails, and chop suey with taro or banana.  She is very popular because she provides a good product and gives good service.

Her sales are approximately 500 tala per day, which she uses to purchase food supplies, repay loans that she has received from SPBDF in the past, and to provide for the needs of her family.

She now wants to borrow an additional $1,200 to purchase food supplies and building materials to further expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase lamb crops, mutton flap, turkey tail. Soy sauce, plastic plates                   (HI)= cement, timber, nail

loans.name: Pe'a

texts.en:
Pe'a, 59, is a talented seamstress who is the sole provider for her family.  Her children are grown, but because her children were unable to complete their education due to lack of family funds, they are still living at home with no jobs or stable future.

Pe'a is applying for a loan of $1,000 to enable her to purchase materials and supplies in order to enable her to open a small business selling clothing and performing seamstress services.

She wants to build some savings so that when she passes on her kids will have something to fall back on.

loans.use: To purchase fabrics and sewing materials

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Vaiutu

texts.en:
Vaiutu specializes in the preparation of baked taro, breadfruit and luau to sell at the local open air market.  She sells primarily to workers who purchase her products to take home for their children or elderly parents who remain home during the day.  The food is already prepared and proves to be a great convenience.

She makes approximately 150 tala per week, or more depending on the sales for the week.  She uses this money to provide for her family and to repay the current loan that she has from SPBDF.

Vaiutu is applying for another loan in the amount of $850 to enable her to purchase additional food supplies and building materials for her stall.

loans.use: To purchase Young  taro plant, coconuts, foil, tauaga,	(HI)= timber, iron roofing

loans.name: Saeu

texts.en:
Saeu is a hard-working mother living in Faleula who is seeking to expand her fishing business in order to improve the lot of her family.  Although she has not been in the fishing business very long, living near the ocean for her entire life has given her the knowledge necessary to conduct such a business.

She has succeeded because as soon as she brings her fresh-caught fish to shore, she takes them to a stand at the end of the road or to the local fish market, where she sells them to local restaurants.

She is now applying for a loan of $850 from SPBDF to allow her to purchase additional nets so that she can increase her sales.

loans.use: To acquire more fishing nets

loans.name: Sau

texts.en:
Sau is a proprietor who wants to expand her ice ckae business in order to earn enough money to allow her to send her children to school.

Ice cakes are very popular with young and old alike due to the warm climate of Samoa.  She makes ice cakes and takes them directly to other shops to be sold.  In addition, she sells convenience store items.

After all expenses, she makes $1,000 per week which she uses to provide for her family's needs, expand her business and provide for her children's schooling.

She is applying for a loan of $1,000 from SPDBF to enable her to purchase convenience store stock and building materials.

loans.use: To purchase snacks, soda & beer, cigarettes, milk, KoolAid, plastic cups, (HI) timber, cement nail, iron roofing, etc.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Lanuola

texts.en:
Elei printing is very popular both locally and even overseas. Lanuola makes elei prints at home and delivers them to local flea markets, as well as selling them to tourists and even Samoans residing in foreign lands. 

Strong family support is always behind this business success as the husband is the designer and the children are the sellers.

Normal weekly profit is about 200 tala, but is higher during holiday seasons as elei make good gifts and are used for outfits at holiday parties and functions.

Lanuola is applying for a loan of $1,200 from SPBDF to purchase additional materials.

loans.use: To purchase Paint, screen, design, Material, upeti, etc. (HI) sand, cement, European timber,

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Misiaika

texts.en:
Misiaika is a seamstress by profession, who now desires to start her own business providing sewing services to the people of her village. She has always had a talent for dressmaking and design, and is now anxious to start her own business.

She understands her product and her customers, and believes that these will allow her to be successful in business. She specializes in the traditional puletasi and muumuu, and uses traditional objects in her designs.

She is now applying for a loan of $850 to allow her to purchase a sewing machine.

loans.use: new sewing machine to expand her business.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sauaso

texts.en:
One of the major products from plantations in Samoa is cocoa. Most families in Samoa use cocoa beans daily to produce cocoa for tea. In most households, Samoan cocoa is a delicacy, which is served at breakfast, lunch, and dinner.

Due to the high demand for cocoa in the daily lives of Samoans, Sauaso specializes in manufacturing cocoa from cocoa beans. She caters to local residents as well as the overseas market. 

Sauaso is dedicated and has talent, but she is unable to increase the size of her business because she lacks financial resources.  She is applying for a loan of $800 to expand her inventory of cocoa beans.

loans.use: to purchase more cocoa beans for upgrading her stock.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sela

texts.en:
Sela grew up in Faleula and became a talented fisherman, but at the expense of an education.  As a result, when she was married, she did not have any other marketable skills, and her family lived in poverty.

Under the guidance of SPBD, she has put her fishing skills to good use by establishing a small fishing business that caters to locals.

She has been in business for five years, and is now applying for a loan of $850 in order to purchase a new boat to expand her business in order to improve her living conditions as well as provide an education to her five children so that they will have the opportunities that she did not have.

loans.use: Purchase boat

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sieli

texts.en:
Sieli is a married mother of one who is the sole provider for her family, as her husband is unable to work. 

She gets up every day before sunrise to work on her peanut crop and to deliver her produce to schools, stores and the local open air market.

Sieli is applying for a loan of $900 from SPBDF in order to purchase peanut seed and fertilizer to enable her to increase the quality and quantity of her produce.

loans.use: Finance peanut seeds and fertilizers to improve quality of her produce

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sofai

texts.en:
Sofia comes from a large family where only two people work, but they do not earn enough to supply their growing family with the necessities of life.

She is a skilled fisherman and has decided to put her skills and knowledge to use to provide additional income for her family.

Sofia operates a small fishing business that caters to locals from Faleula as well as local restaurants.

She is applying for a loan of $875 from SPBDF in order to purchase a new net to replace her old one.

loans.use: To buy a new fishing net to replace the old one

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Talaitupu

texts.en:
Talaitupu is an enthusiastic and lively person that believes that no matter how old you are, you are never too old to start something for the good of your children and family.

She has applied to the SPBDF for a loan of $875 to purchase materials that will allow her to start a small business that will allow her to put her talents to good use in order to earn enough to improve her family's standard of living.

Talaitupu focuses primarily on the production of muumuus and puletasis,  Samoa’s traditional wear.

loans.use: To purchase sewing materials such as fabric, needles & thread

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Taliilagi

texts.en:
Taliilagi grew up with the dream of one day owning her own store, and with the help of the SPBDF it is now coming true.

She wants to expand her business in order to improve the life of her family by providing a stable financial base for her family.

She is applying for a loan of $1,000 from the SPBDF in order to expand the number of goods for sale and to expand the size of her store.

loans.use: Expand inventory of goods and expanding the store.

loans.name: Tuloto

texts.en:
Tuloto is married and lives with her husband and 5 children in the village of Aele-Fou where peanut farming is one of the oldest trades.  She and her husband do not currently earn enough to feed, school and clothe their children.

She set up a small business in a field that she has experience in (peanut farming), in order to improve her family's standard of living.  She loves her children dearly and wants to give them something to live for when they grow older.  All her efforts are for her children's future.

She is applying for a loan of $650 from the SPBDF to purchase peanut seeds and fertilizer to start her own business.

loans.use: Buy bags of peanut seeds and fertilizers and pesticides

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Epi

texts.en: Epi, 38, is married with three children. She maintains a vegetable garden and makes taro chips to sell in a flea market that she operates in her front yard, earning her 200-300 tala a week. Before she obtained her first loan from SPBD, Epi was a full time house wife who relied heavily on relatives from overseas for financial support. SPBD has assisted Epi and has given her ideas to start and build her business.  Epi desires to borrow an additional $850 to enable her to buy fruits and vegetables for her flea market stall. This loan would be her 4th loan and she is a member of the Mataufu Centre.

loans.use: For working capital to buy and sell fruits and vegetables in her flea market stall

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Faatamalii

texts.en:
Faatamalii, 53, is a mother of six who runs a beach resort in Saleapaga.  She earns 300-600 tala  a week catering to tourists from Aggie Grey's and many others.
Faatamalii was unemployed until she joined the SPBDF program in 2003 and started her own business to support her family.  She has had 4 previous loans, and now wishes to borrow an $1,000 to purchase two additional cabanas.
Faatamalii is one of the top business women in the SPBD program.

loans.use: To build two additional beach cottages (fale) to expand her resort business

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Galuega

texts.en:
Galuega, 32, is a married mother of two who started her Elei printing business in 2004 with the help of the SPBDF.  She designs and prints Eleis and sells them through grocery stores in her district, earning 300-500 tala per week.

Galuega is the breadwinner of her extended family which also includes three brothers and two sisters.

She now wants to borrow an additional $875 to purchase additional materials for her printing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics, paints, stencils and other materials for her elei printing business.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Laukiana

texts.en:
Laukiana,46,is a widow with eight children and grandchildren.  Her  husband died a few years ago.  She wants to expand her bakery business to support her eight children and grandchildren's school fees.  Prior to joining the SPBDF program, she was unemployed and relied upon money sent from relatives living in New Zealand.

Laukiana received her first loan from the SPBDF in 2003 when she started her bakery business. She sells her products to pre-schools and primary schools in her village and nearby villages and earns 200 tala per week.

She now wishes to borrow an additional $1,200 in order to purchase supplies and equipment that will allow her to sell to more schools in nearby villages.

loans.use: To purchase additional flour, sugar, shortening and baking equipment to expand her business.

loans.name: Lemapu

texts.en:
Lemapu, 37, is a mother of four who has a small taro plantation.  Before joining the SPBDF program, she was unemployed and relied upon family overseas for funds.

The SPBDF helped Lemapu expand her family's plantation from which she sells three or four sacks of taro per week, earning her 300-400 tala per week.

She wishes to borrow an additional $875 to enable her to purchase fertilizer, chemicals and fungicides  for her farm to expand her sales in order to finance her children's school fees.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, chemicals and fungicides for her taro farm.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand and diversify my business

loans.name: Sylivia

texts.en: I am a 32 year old mother of 4. I sell masai cloths.  I take care of other 2 children.  I will grow my business expend products and earn more.

loans.use: I intent to expand and diversify my business

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: I am a father of 3, aged 34 years. I sell secondhand men's clothes. I also take care of my parents and 3 children of my late brother. I wish to earn more money through diversifying my business.

loans.use: I intend to expand and diversify my business.

loans.name: Miller

texts.en: I am a father of 3, aged 34 years. I am a painter. I also take care of my parents and my brother's children. I wish to earn more money through dairy farming.

loans.use: I will use the money to purchase a dairy goat.

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: I am a father of 3, aged 34 years. I am a painter. I also take care of my parents.  . I wish to earn more by diversifying and advertising my business to the building industry.

loans.use: Purchase working tools

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en: I am a grandmother with 23 grandchildren. My 4 daughters died of HIV/AIDS. I sell school boxes. I do my business in Bumala, in Busia district. I am the main breadwinner for my family. I believe this loan will help me increase my business skills and educate my dependents.

loans.use: I will use the loan to widen my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business to shoe vending and other quarters.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand and diversify my business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: I am a single girl aged 19 and I am a tailor. I need the money to expand my business and be able to meet my college fees and increase my skills in the business sector.

loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Tang

texts.en:
Tang is 38 years old. He had his wife, Ha, have 4 children between 14 and 5. Tang suffers from chronic bronchitis and cannot do much strenuous work. Their 2 youngest children are epileptic: Tang and Ha had to sell a piece of land to pay for the numerous medical visits and treatments. But the children are better now.

Tang's family has only a small hut and a little more than 1 hectare of agriculture land. The land is poor and they have no capital, so they lend it out to a neighbor.

Tang has repaid his first loan of $50. He became free from the local moneylender and increased his daily profit from just 75 cents to $1 now. He wants to borrow for another cycle of 7 months. His long-term dream is to plant cashew trees on their land.

loans.use: Small waste recycling business

loans.name: Anh

texts.en:
Anh's husband had cardiac problems 8 years ago, and the family spent much money to save him, so now they have no land left. Today he can hardly walk and watches the house while Anh sells at the market. Fortunately the neighbors are very helpful. The family has received a scholarship to keep their 2 children at school. Until recently the total family income was only $32 per month.

They have repaid a first loan of $50, so they freed themselves from usurious loans, for which they spent $10 per month for interest only. Progressively their family income has risen to $38 (+19%).

Today they want another loan of $50 to consolidate their position. Later, their long term wish is to rent 2 hectares of land to plant cassava.

loans.use: Vegetable retail stand in the local market, plus sale of lottery tickets.

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela has been in the business of selling clothes for the last three years. She is also a water vendor. Pamela is married and has three children who attend school. She received one loan from Kenya Women Finance Trust which boosted her business and enabled her to repay the loan.

Now she is seeking another loan to so she can boost her business again by buying clothes in bulk. She will use her profit increase to educate her children. She also plans to accumulate enough savings to buy a plot and build a house for her family.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Carolyne is married and has two children who are attend school. She has been in the business of selling cereals for the last two years. A previous loan from SMEP increased her business and made it possible to employ an assistant.

With this loan, she will reduce be able to buy cereals in bulk and increase her profits once more. As her business grows, she will use the profits to build a house for her family so they don't have to rent. She will also build her own store, educate her children and get provide them with medical care.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock for her business.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is married and has one child. He has been in the ice cream business for the three years, mainly serving school children. He is educated to level 8, but was unable to afford school fees for further education.

He will use his loan to buy a fridge which will enable him to serve more schools in Kisumu.

He will use his profits to open a business for his wife, educate the children, and furnish his house. He also will help his aging parents.

loans.use: purchase of equipment

loans.name: Vera

texts.en:
Vera is married with two children. After graduating from medical school, she worked as a nurse in a laboratory. In 2003 Vera decided to become self-employed. She rented a vending facility and started her own business selling phyto chemical products that are beneficial to human health. Vera received her first loan from “Nadiya Ukraine” in June of 2004. She used the money to increase the assortment of phyto concentrates she offered in her store. Good quality, nutritious products rich in amino acids, vitamins and minerals have found wide acceptance with healthy eaters. Moreover, Vera has enjoyed being able to help many of her customers with their health problems. Vera is requesting $500 to increase her supply of phyto products. The loan will help her purchase a variety of phyto chemicals, natural extracts, and essential oils that are used as pharmaceuticals and also in the cosmetic and food industries. A range of phyto products including an anti-cancer precursor, anti-oxidants, anti-inflammatory and hypertensive products, sweeteners, and food supplements will help Vera continue to meet her customer’s needs for total health and wellness.

Віра – одружена, в неї двоє дітей. В неї медична освіта, вона певний час працювала лаборантом. В 2003 році Віра вирішила почати власний бізнес. Вона орендувала торгівельне приміщення та почала торгувати фітопрепаратами, які є дуже корисними для здоров’я людини. Віра отримала першу позику від «Надії України» ще в червні 2004 року. Вона використала отримані гроші для того, щоб розширити асортимент фітоконцентратів у власній крамничці. Якісні продукти, багаті на амінокислоти, вітаміни та мінерали користуються високим попитом серед людей, які намагаються дотримуватися здорового образу життя. Більш за все Вірі подобається допомагати багатьом покупцям з вирішенням їхніх проблем зі здоров’ям. Віра просить про позику в 500 доларів для того, щоб збільшити асортимент фітопрепаратів. Позика допоможе їй закупити різноманітні фітопродукти, натуральні екстракти, природні масла, які використовуються в фармацевтичній, косметичній та харчовій промисловості. Широкий вибір фітоконцентратів, а саме, засобів, що попереджують появлення ракових пухлин та знижують тиск, антиоксидантів, протизапальних препаратів, цукрозамінників та харчових добавок надасть Вірі можливість й надалі допомагати її клієнтам із вирішенням певних проблем зі здоров’ям та самопочуттям.

loans.use: To increase the supply of phyto products

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is married with one teenage son and is the only breadwinner in his family. Several years ago his father became seriously ill. Ivan had to look after him during the day which meant he could only work at night. That is why Ivan decided to become a taxi driver. He has been in business for 10 years now and makes around $30-40 per day. Ivan is a very determined, hard-worker – sometimes working 24 hours a day. A year ago he underwent a serious surgery on one of his kidneys. This challenge didn’t affect his business, however. After recovering, Ivan went right back to work and his business continued to be profitable and sustainable. Seventeen loans from “Nadiya Ukraine” have also been instrumental in the success of Ivan’s business. Ivan would like to receive a loan to help purchase a newer vehicle. A comfortable and reliable car will enable him to serve more clients, handle tough competition and expand his business. Profits generated will not only promote continued growth for Ivan’s business but will also provide a good income for his family.

Іван – одружений, в нього є син підліток. Він один забезпечує родину. Декілька років тому його батько серйозно захворів. Іван був змушений доглядати його вдень, працювати ж він міг лише вночі. Саме тому Іван вирішив заробляти працюючи таксистом. Він займається цим бізнесом вже 10 років, щодня заробляє приблизно 30-40 доларів. Іван – дуже рішучий та працьовитий. Іноді він працює 24 години на добу. Рік тому він переніс складну операцію на одній з нирок. Однак. ці труднощі не вплинули на стабільність його бізнесу. Після одужання Іван повернувся до роботи, його бізнес продовжував приносити прибуток. Сімнадцять позик, які він отримав від «Надії України», також відіграли важливу роль в розвитку його бізнесу. Іван хотів би отримати позику для того, щоб придбати новіше авто. Зручний та надійний автомобіль допоможе йому обслуговувати більшу кількість клієнтів, витримати важку конкуренцію та розширити власний бізнес. Отриманий прибуток й надалі сприятиме розвитку бізнесу Івана та забезпечить гідний рівень життя для його родини.

loans.use: To buy a newer vehicle

loans.name: Olena

texts.en:
Olena is married with two children. Eight years ago she decided to start a business selling construction supplies when a difficult financial situation in the family forced her to look for a stable source of income. Today Olena rents a small store in downtown Ivano-Frankivsk and three vending kiosks in the local market. She currently has about $6,000 in working capital and her monthly net profit amounts to $1,200. She is the only breadwinner in the family. Olena is a focused hard-worker. Her experience in the construction supply trade and reasonable pricing policy has helped to keep her business stable for many years. Lending services from “Nadiya Ukraine” have also had a big part in the consistent growth of Olena’s business. She has taken out and repaid a total of 15 loans. Recently, she was able to open three new vending kiosks in the market with financing from a loan. One of Olena’s long term plans is to rent another more spacious vending facility in downtown Ivano-Frankivsk. Olena would like to get a loan of $1,200 to purchase 20 fillet sets (200 items each) to sell in her stores. This financial assistance will help Olena increase her sales and grow her business as a result. Not only will it help her get the necessary inventory and attract more customers, but it will help Olena meet the needs of her family and provide a better livelihood for them.

Олена – одружена, в неї двоє дітей. Вісім років тому вона вирішила почати власний бізнес з продажу будівельних матеріалів, до чого її спонукало скрутне фінансове становище родини. Олена орендує невеличку крамничку в центрі Івано-Франківську, до того ж має три торгівельні точки на місцевому ринку. В неї зараз приблизно 6000 доларів робочого капіталу, щомісячний прибуток складає 1200 доларів. Вона одна забезпечує родину. Олена наполеглива та працьовита. Багатий досвід торгівлі в цій сфері та помірні ціни сприяли стабільному зростанню її бізнесу на протязі цих років. Позики від «Надії України» також відіграли неабияку роль в розширенні бізнесу Олени. Вона отримала та сплатила 15 позик. Завдяки фінансовій підтримці вона нещодавно мала змогу відкрити три нових торгівельних точки. В майбутньому Олена планує розширити власний бізнес та орендувати ще одне торгівельне приміщення в центрі міста. Олена хотіла б отримати позику в 1200 доларів для того щоб придбати 20 сортів багет (по 200 штук) для продажу у крамничці. Фінансова підтримка сприятиме збільшенню обсягів продажу та зростанню бізнесу Олени. Позика не тільки допоможе їй придбати необхідний товар та привабити більше покупців, але й забезпечить нагальні потреби її родини, якісно покращуючи рівень життя кожного з них.

loans.use: To purchase 20 fillet sets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his clothes selling business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her food vending buniness

loans.name: Roza

texts.en: Roza B. bakes very tasty meat rissoles, patties and buns. The recipe of preparation Roza got from her mother who is already 86 years old. Roza starts her cooking at 4 o’clock in the morning. The traders from the local market take her goods from her home at 7 in the morning. She has many clients and mostly she and her daughter are not able to manage the demand. They need more assistants and bigger premises. In April Roza plans to rent a café, where she will cook national dishes and bake. The loan will be used in creating conditions for work in the café and buying additional appliances for cooking. Roza and her daughter love Tajikistan and want to be involved in development of their motherland.

loans.use: Preparation of new premises for work

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina is a divorced mother with one son. In order to provide for herself and her son, she started a small business selling children’s clothing in one of the local markets. Marina has been in this business for over 8 years. It is the only source of income for her family. Marina received her first loan from “Nadiya Ukraine” in 2002. Since then she has repaid 18 loans with no defaults. Operating a successful business has certainly not always been easy for Marina. Her determination and hard work have helped to keep her business stable, even after she was diagnosed with cancer and underwent a serious surgery. Marina needs some additional working capital and that is why she is requesting a loan of $1,200. She is planning to purchase children’s sweaters, T-shirts, skirts and shorts at wholesale prices to sell in her kiosk. The loan will not only help her buy more merchandise and expand her sales but will also provide a better quality of life for her and her son. Being a good steward with the money she receives, we are confident Marina will manage this loan efficiently and repay it in time.

Марина – розлучена, в неї є син. Для того, щоб забезпечити потреби родини, вона почала власний бізнес з продажу дитячого одягу на одному з місцевих ринків. Марина займається торгівлею в цій сфері вже понад 8 років. Її бізнес – єдине джерело прибутку для родини. Марина отримала першу позику від „Надії України” в 2002 році. З того часу вона сплатила 18 позик без жодних прострочень. Звичайно, бізнес Марини не одразу став успішним. Проте, її наполеглива важка праця допомогла їй зберегти стабільність власного бізнесу, навіть не дивлячись на діагноз рак та серйозну операцію, яку їй довелося перенести. Марина хотіла б збільшити власний робочий капітал, саме тому вона просить про позику в1200 доларів. Вона планує закупити дитячі светри, футболки, спіднички та шорти за оптовими цінами для подальшого роздрібного продажу. Позика не тільки допоможе їй придбати більше товарів та збільшити обсяги продажів, але й забезпечить краще життя для неї та її сина. Ми переконані, що вміння розумно витрачати отримані кошти допоможе Марині мудро використати цю позику та вчасно її сплатити.

loans.use: To increase sales stock

loans.name: Samiboy

texts.en:
Samiboy has two children, a daughter of 4 years and a son of 6 years. He has been working as a baker for 12 years. After graduating from secondary school, he entered Tajik University, but during his third year he had to leave it, due to lack of money. So he came back to his bakery. Now he has 3 assistants in the bakery and one shop assistant in the market. He wants to buy the ingredients in larger volume at a lower price. Therefore he will use his loan to buy flour for the bread.
His goal is to increase his business and use the profit for the future education of his children.

loans.use: Purchase of flour

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla is divorced and has two children. Her main source of income is from a small business she runs selling sewing, quilting and embroidery supplies in one of the local markets. She has been in business for 9 years. Alla has been working with “Nadiya Ukraine” since 2005. She has received and promptly repaid 9 loans with no defaults. Financial assistance has promoted growth in her sales and the expansion of her business. Competitive prices and top-quality merchandise have helped her gain many loyal customers. Currently, Alla has about $2,800 of working capital. Her monthly net profit amounts to $500. Alla would like to receive a loan of $900 to increase her working capital. She is planning to purchase buttons, fringe, elastic, feathers, lace and sequin trims, thread, zippers, needles and pins in bulk for further retail sale. Alla believes a wide assortment of ethnic textiles, dancewear fabrics, beads and different accessories will attract many more potential clients to her kiosk. The loan will not only increase her working capital and sales, but will promote the continued expansion of Alla’s business.

Алла – розлучена, в неї двоє дітей. В неї є власний бізнес з продажу товарів для шиття, в’язання та вишивання на одному з місцевому ринків. Алла займається цим бізнесом вже на протязі 9 років. Алла співпрацює з „Надією України” з 2005 року. Вона отримала та вчасно сплатила 9 позик без жодних прострочень. Фінансова допомога сприяла збільшенню обсягів продажу та розширенню її бізнесу. Прийнятні ціни та високоякісні товари допомогли їй знайти багато відданих клієнтів. Зараз в Алли приблизно 2800 доларів робочого капіталу. Щомісячний прибуток складає 500 доларів. Алла хотіла б отримати позику в 900 доларів для того, щоб збільшити робочий капітал. Вона планує закупити ґудзики, бахрому, гумові матеріали, пір’я, тасьму, блискітки, нитки, застібки, голки та шпильки оптом задля подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Алла вважає, що великий асортимент тканин з українськими візерунками, необхідних дрібничок для танцювальних костюмів, намистинок та різноманітних аксесуарів приваблять багато потенціальних клієнтів до її кіоску. Позика не тільки збільшить її робочий капітал та обсяги продажів, але й сприятиме подальшому зростанню бізнесу Алли.

loans.use: To increase her working capital

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two daughters. When she opened her small vending kiosk she literally started from nothing. Her family was in a very tough financial situation, but Irina decided to take a risk and start a small business selling pet food, treats and accessories in the local market. Presently, she has about $10,000 in working capital and a monthly net profit of around $1,000. Irina has been working with “Nadiya Ukraine” since 2001. She has received and promptly repaid each of the 13 loans she has received from the organization. Recently her grandson underwent a serious surgery which required a lot of money from the family. Irina spent most of her time with her grandson while he was in the hospital. However, she managed not only to keep her business open and sustainable but also to increase her sales volume within that period. Irina would like to receive a loan of $1,200 to increase her inventory. She is planning to purchase a variety of pet supplies such as feeders, bowls, mats, collars, leashes, toys, and canned and dry pet food. She believes a good assortment of supplies for dogs, cats, birds, small animals and fish will meet the needs of many more pet owners and help them get the right food or product for their pets. This loan will not only help Irina re-stock her inventory and boost her sales but will also help her earn enough to maintain her family and provide a better livelihood for them.

Ірина – одружена, в неї є дві дочки. Коли вона лише почала працювати у власному маленькому кіоску на одному з місцевих ринків, в неї буквально нічого не було. Її родина опинилася у дуже важкому фінансовому становищі, отже, Ірина вирішила ризикнути та почати власний бізнес з продажу корму, іграшок та різних аксесуарів для домашніх тварин. Зараз в неї приблизно 10000 доларів робочого капіталу, щомісячний прибуток складає 1000 доларів. Ірина співпрацює з „Надією України” з 2001 року. Вона отримала та вчасно сплатила усі 13 позик, які отримала в нашій організації. Нещодавно її онук переніс серйозну операцію, потрібно було багато грошей. Ірина більшість часу проводила зі своїм онуком, поки він перебував у лікарні. Однак, їй вдалося не тільки зберегти прибутковість власного бізнесу, але й збільшити обсяги продажів за цей період. Ірина хотіла б отримати позику в 1200 доларів для того, щоб збільшити кількість товару. Вона планує закупити різноманітні товари для домашніх тварин, а саме, миски, килимки, нашийники, повідці, іграшки, консервований та сухий корм для домашніх улюбленців. Вона вважає, що розмаїття товарів для собак, котів, птахів, малих тварин та рибок допоможе їй задовольнити потреби багатьох власників домашніх тварин, підібрати правильне харчування та продукти для своїх улюбленців. Ця позика допоможе Ірині не тільки розширити асортимент товарів та збільшити обсяги продажів, але й допоможе їй забезпечувати потреби родини та гарантувати кращий рівень життя для її рідних.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand his clothes selling business

loans.name: Shokir

texts.en: Shokir has three children. His wife is a housewife. He rents a mini- shop to produce knitted garments. There are five women in his workshop. All of them have big families. Two of these women are also receiving loans from MicroInvest.  They produce different kind of cardigans, vests, sweaters and pullovers. Their goal is to develop their production,  to improve the quality of their products and, as a result, to increase the number of clients. To obtain better quality it is necessary to buy new equipment and high quality raw materials. After the number of clients increase, Shokir would like to hire more assistants in his shop.

loans.use: Production of knitted garments

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua is 26 years old and mother of 1 child. She operates a food distribution shop in one of the major surburbs in the city. Her wares include rice, cooking oil, provisions, and children's snacks. As a beneficiary of the TEACH sessions provided by KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION, she is in a better position to utilise the requested loan to expand her business with additional food products.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her clothes selling business

loans.name: Barbara

texts.en:
Barbara is a young woman of 27 with no dependents. She runs a store which sells edible fats and oils. She was initially set up in the business by her mother. Over the last 8 months, her business shows a consistent increase in sales. Moreover, her clientele has gone up from ten to fifteen. They include bakers, confectionary and pastry makers.

She has been a beneficiary of KRABAN'S TEACH sessions since October 2006. She needs the KIVA loan to augment her capital to stock more items to meet customer needs.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Raquel

texts.en:
Raque M. is 48 years old and from the city of Maputo. She is married and has two children. Her parents did not have the financial means to provide for her studies beyond the 6th grade. In 1986 she took over the family business located in the neighborhood of Xipamanine in Maputo. For family reasons, she had to move to the rural district of Boane where she established a small shop in the local market. In 2006 friends, neighbors and other store owners introduced her to Hluvuku-Adsema where she got her first loan to grow her business. The amount was very small but it gave her a chance to learn how to manage credit. Now her business is going well and provides employment to three workers (two women and a man). With the profits from her business she has created a Xitique (a local form of savings account). Daily she supports the school fees of three children. With the loan of 10,000,000MT she intends to increase her stock of products. Her business has a large impact on the community. In addition to providing a service she also guarantees the employment of three other people, brings products closer to the customer, and provides refreshments to all the merchants and drivers at the market. She hopes to grow her business to best meet the needs of the market and to also increase the size of her home which is no longer big enough for her current circumstances.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva Volunteer Julie Lerch

Raquel M. de 48 anos de idade, natural da cidade do Maputo, casada, mãe de 2 filhos. Cresceu sob a responsabilidade dos pais que tiveram poucas possibilidades financeiras para proporcionar lhe estudos para alem de sexta classe. Desde 1986 no bairro de Xipamanine na cidade do Maputo vem assumindo na integra a gestão de negocio da família. Por motivos famílias teve de mudar de residência para o distrito rural de Boane, onde adquiriu um pequeno estabelecimento comercial no mercado local. A partir de 2006 por indicação de amigas e vizinhas, também comerciantes, teve conhecimento da existência da Hluvuku-Adsema, tendo aproximado e solicitado o primeiro empréstimo para ampliação do seu negocio, embora o valor foi tão insignificante deu para aprender a lidar com crédito. Actualmente, o seu negocio esta num bom ritmo razoável e providencia emprego para três trabalhadores (duas senhoras e um homem), com os rendimentos do negocio tem feito Xitique (prática local de poupanças), diariamente, suporta as despesas escolares de 3 filhos. Com empréstimo de 10.000.00 MT, pretende aumentar o volume de mercadoria. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque alem de providenciar serviços, também garante postos de trabalho para ela própria mais outras 3 pessoas, coloca o produto mais perto do cliente, com particular destaque para todos vendedores do mercado e motoristas de chapas que lhes providencia refeições. Tem como perspectivas, fazer crescer o negócio e fazer de forma mais convencional possível para satisfazer as necessidades do mercado e ampliar a sua habitação que está já não se adequa a realidade actual.

loans.use: To increase the stock of products in her shop

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina Carmona F. is 42 years old and originally from Maputo. She is married, but while growing up she lost her mother when she was just 8 years old. Her family's financial situation did not allow her to study. Since 1981 she has been working in her family's business in Boane at a store in the local Boane market. In 2006 friends and neighbors introduced her to Hluvuku-Adsema. She became a member and obtained a loan to grow her business. Her business grew to a new level and she applied for other loans. Now her business is doing very well and provides employment to one worker (her son). The profits from her business have helped her meet her daily needs, cover the school expenses of her two children, and improve the the condition of her home. She plans to use the loan of 13,000,000MT to increase her stock and the variety of products. Her business has a large impact on the community. In addition to providing a usefull service she also provides the school with students' uniforms.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva Volunteer Julie Lerch

Madina Carmona F. de 42 anos de idade, natural de Maputo, casada maritalmente cresceu sob a responsabilidade dos pais, onde veio a perder a sua mãe quando tinha apenas 8 anos de idade, a situação financeira da família lhe criou poucas oportunidades para estudar. Desde 1981 no Distrito de Boane vem assumindo na integra a gestão de negocio da família e possui uma banca comercial no mercado de boane. A partir do ano 2006, por curiosidade de amigas e vizinhas também elas comerciantes teve conhecimento da existência da Hluvuku-Adsema, tendo aproximado e solicitado um empréstimo para ampliação do seu negocio. Desde então, o seu negocio conheceu outra dinâmica tendo solicitado outros empréstimo. Actualmente, o seu negocio esta num bom ritmo e providencia emprego um trabalhador (seu filho homem), com os rendimentos do negocio tem lhe ajudado muito para o próprio sustento diário, suporte de despesas escolares para 2 filhos e no melhoramento das condições da sua residência. Com empréstimo de 13.000,00 MT, pretende aumentar o stock e diversificar os artigos. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade porque para alem de proporcionar emprego para ela própria mais o filho, presta um serviço útil para sua comunidade, com particular destaque para todos residentes nas redondezas do mercado e comunidade escolar com uniformes para alunos.

loans.use: To increase the stock of products in her shop

loans.name: Ayishetu

texts.en: Ayi is 52 years old and the mother of 7 children, all in school. The father of the children is jobless and feeble. Ayi therefore sells cereals to provide for her family. She needs the KIVA loan to expand her operation and to be able to get her 7 children through basic schooling. She has benefited from the KRABAN 'TEACH' learning sessions.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose i[. 51 year[. old and a civil servant in retirement. She i[. married with 6 children, some of who[. are attending school at the senio[. and junio[. level[.. She i[. a distribute[. of flou[. in he[. area. She i[. supplied by the Takoradi Flou[. Mill[. directly. With the increase in custome[. base, the need ha[. arisen fo[. additional capital to meet custome[. demand[.. Thu[. the KIVA loan will come in handy to help he[. to satisfy he[. client[..

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Erkin

texts.en: Erkin is a resident of Spitamen, a small village type town near Khujand. Before August 2003, Erkin was engaged in trade of essential commodities in the Spitamen Food market, had a small assortment, and his actives were insignificant. He has a wife and two daughters. The food market was far away from the street where he lives and he always thought that it would be good idea to open a shop in his own neighborhood. He invested all his profit into this idea. At the beginning Erkin’s shop consisted only of one table, where all his goods were placed. His shop is known for low prices and always-fresh goods. He constantly worked on expansion of his assortment and the quality of the sold goods. He brings the goods from the big market in the city. Now he wants to build additional shelves in his shop and will use his loan for that. He wants to achieve a day when buyers can find all necessary things in his shop.

loans.use: Retail trade of essential commodities

loans.name: Muattar

texts.en: The first loan Muattar received in May of 2003 was only $70. At that time she had only 2 years of experience in trade and was engaged in the sale of children's clothes at “Proletarsk” clothes market.  Her trading space consisted of 2 meters and the assortment of the goods included only the most necessary for successful trade. For getting more profit it was necessary to invest additional capital and that’s why she came to MicroInvest for a loan. Мuattar invested the total loan amount into an increasing the number and assortment of goods. At that time she did not use her profit for family expenses and invested it all back into her business. Her husband took care of her and their two children. She thinks that fact helped her to increase the volume of her business and to succeed. Recently she has approached the market administration about the increase of a trading place and now it is 4 meters.  She learned that trade of children’s shoes could be very profitable and could be a next step for development of her business. She will use her loan to buy various footwear for the spring and summer season.

loans.use: Retail trade of children clothes

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Matluba

texts.en: In May of 2002 Matluba Aziziova and her sister started their small business of sewing female dresses and selling them. They had a small assortment and turnover of the business was slow. Her sister was mainly engaged in sewing and she was selling those dresses at “Chorshanbe” market. Together they earned about 175 dollars per month. Matluba wished to expand the  assortment and instead of buying fabric from other traders bring the fabric  herself from Uzbekistan and Kyrgystan. She wants to bring fabric both for sale and for her sister to produce dresses and that way to decrease the cost of each dress. Together with her colleagues she will travel to wholesale markets by bus. It usually takes between 1 to 5 days for one trip depending on the location.

loans.use: Retail trade of female dresses

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Julie is 27 years old with no children. She deals in the sale of children's wear. In addition,she sells rubber footwear for adults as well as provisions. She has this business for the past 3 years in a rented premises. She wants to utilise the KIVA loan to erect a permanent structure of her own. It is her expectation that this would help stabilise her income.

loans.use: Structure, premises

loans.name: Abibatu

texts.en: Abi is 25 years old and married with 1 child. She runs a small food joint which is well patronised, mostly in the evenings. She began this about a year ago and has to procure her stock on credit from her suppliers. Having taken part in the TEACH learning sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION, she heard of the KIVA loan. She has therefore applied for the amount to use as seed capital to pay upfront for her inventory.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Rahinatu

texts.en: Rahi is 27 years old and single. She started a small business last year selling swan timber to individuals and small business owners in the construction industry. There has been phenomenal growth over the past 6 months especially. This has resulted in the need for additional capital to expand her operations to meet the ever-increasing demand, specifically from those roofing their buildings. She therefore deems the KIVA loan a great opportunity to take full advantage of as soon as possible.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en: Faustie is 30 years old and mother of 2 children. She sells rice porridge in the mornings to children going to school and fresh foodstuff in her community from late afternoon to evening. She procures the foodstuff from the hinterland normally over the weekends. She intends to use the KIVA loan to put up a structure in which to display her goods.

loans.use: Structure/Premises

loans.name: Gracious

texts.en: Gracious is a widowed mother of 3 children. Her husband died early last year. This has made it difficult for her to pay school fees for the children. With the assistance of some friends, she managed to secure a charcoal sales business in front of their rented premises. Even though sales are good, household expenses take a great chunk of the profits with almost nothing to reinvest. She is therefore very keen to secure the KIVA loan to augment her dwindling capital.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Alima

texts.en:
Alima is 45 years old and a mother of 9 children, some of whom are in school. Even though she is married, her husband is not earning any income to support the household expenditures. She therefore sells some household items to support herself and the children as well as her husband. These items include bread, suger, washing detergents and charcoal.

Having participated in KRABAN'S 'TEACH' learning sessions last year, she is in a better position to manage the loan from KIVA if granted.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Barikisu

texts.en: Barikisu is 24 years old, married with 2 children. The husband is currently living in Accra where he is working. She therefore has to cope with the upkeep of herself and the 2 children. She sells fresh tomatoes in her community through the day. She needs the KIVA loan to support her meagre capital to be able to buy additional crates for onward sale to her clients. She also has the objective of acquiring a permanent place as a base.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Aggie is 22 years old and mother of 2 children. She operates a hair salon in her surburb. She has the basic facilities but needs additional products, conditioning oils, shampoos, etc. As a student of KRABAN'S 'TEACH' learning sessions, Aggie is poised to make the maximum use of the KIVA loan if granted.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas is 29 years old, married and has one child. He lives within the Kibera slums with his other two siblings since his parents are now old and reside in the Western Province of Kenya. Nicholas supports his siblings mainly by paying for their school fees. Nicholas has a standard eight education (Primary Level) but is keen to see his siblings get quality education, something he was not able to get because his parents could not afford the school fees.

The poor conditions from his home area in Western Province drove Nicholas to come to the city of Nairobi and live with his uncle in Kibera at an early age of 14 years. It was during that period that Nicholas went through vocational training in shoe making at the Makina market within Kibera slums through support from his uncle. His uncle paid $ 65 over a period of eight months where he was attached to a shoemaker and was learning through apprenticeship. He continued to get the shoe making skills for two years (1992 to 1994) without a pay even after the eight months period of learning had elapsed.
