Nicholas has now been involved in the business of mending shoes for now 12 years, and he is proud of his work. This is because he is making a difference in someone’s life. Through his business, he has received tenders from the Meridian Hotel, a hotel in Nairobi, to make shoes for their staff. He also gets tenders from sponsored Primary Schools within Kibera.

Given the loan of $50, which is repayable over a period of 6 – 12 months, Nicholas plans to purchase a sewing machine through which he can be doing all the stitching individually. Nicholas cuts leather, makes designs, and mends shoes. Since he does not have a sewing machine to do the stitches, he usually takes the shoes he has designed to be stitched to the machine of a friend. This has proved costly since he pays slightly less than a dollar for every pair that needs to be stitched. In a week he is able to make six pairs of shoes, while during peak seasons, he makes 10 pairs. His customers usually have to wait for two to three days for their shoes to be ready. This has contributed to having his customers looking for other places where the services are faster. Nicholas seeks to change this to be able to retain his customers.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine for shoes

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en: Angela is 28 years old and married with 1 child. She runs a hair salon which is well patronised. She intends to add 'con-roll' and other hair plaiting styles to her range of available services. She wants to use the KIVA loan to purchase inventory like hair mesh and an additional hair-dryer to meet customers' demands.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Retailing of general goods has been a past-time of Doris K.. She trades in a variety of consumer goods in her community. She has been a trainee of Kraban Support Foundation's TEACH Lending Skills program. She wants a KIVA loan of $900 to improve her business capital.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more stock of men's clothes

loans.name: Abraham

texts.en: Abraham is 29 years old and single. He runs a general store in the central business district of the city. Items for sale include flour, sugar, margarine, and heavy-duty transformers. With a big client base, he intends to use the KIVA loan to  increase his stock in the coming months to able to meet customer demand. He has undergone 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en: Theresa is involved in produce sales. She buys and sells farm produce to neighbouring communities and markets. The community she resides in is near the Capital City, Accra. She is a graduate of the Teach Lending prgramm of Kraban Support Foundation. She requires a loan of $925 to improve her business.

loans.use: Working CAPITAL

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is 30 years old, married with 2 children. She is in the hairdressing business. Although she has her own salon, she operates with a single hair-dryer. Her objective therefore is to secure the KIVA loan to purchase two more to able to serve at least 3 clients at a time. She graduated from KRABAN'S TEACH learning sessions in October 2006.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her clothing business

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is married with two sons. She started out as an entrepreneur selling clothing for women in the central city market. However, later she decided to change the type inventory she offered and began to sell knitted wear for men instead. Today, after 10 years, her business is the only source of income for her family and her husband and elder son are actively involved, helping her with sales. Currently, she has about $2,000 of working capital available and her monthly net profit amounts to $900. Nataliya is a very focused and balanced business owner. She has received and promptly repaid 18 loans from “Nadiya Ukraine”. Her hard work together with financial support has promoted the stable growth of her trade. Nataliya is requesting a loan of $1,000 to re-stock her inventory. She is planning to purchase 30 smooth men’s sweaters, 40 wool roll-neck pullovers and 50 trendy caps and hats at wholesale prices for further retail sale. A good assortment of inventory at reasonable prices will attract many potential customers to her kiosk, helping her business to grow and expand for the future. Nataliya is also planning to invest part of the generated profits in another small business venture. She would like to expand on a hobby she enjoys and open two small vending kiosks to sell plants, flower seeds and fertilizer during the spring season.

Наталя – одружена, в неї двоє синів. Вона почала власний бізнес з торгівлі жіночим одягом на центральному ринку. Проте, пізніше вона вирішила змінити тип товарів та почала торгувати чоловічим трикотажем. Зараз, після 10 років роботи в цій сфері, її бізнес є єдиним джерелом прибутку для усієї родини. Чоловік та син активно допомагають Наталі в торгівлі. В неї приблизно 2000 доларів робочого капіталу, її щомісячний прибуток складає 900 доларів. Наталя – дуже рішучий та зважений підприємець. Вона отримала та вчасно сплатила 18 позик від „Надії України”. Її наполеглива праця у поєднанні з фінансовою підтримкою сприяла стабільному росту її торгівлі. Наталя просить про позику в 1000 для того, щоб розширити свій асортимент. Вона планує закупити 30 теплих чоловічих светрів, 40 вовняних пуловерів та 50 модних капелюшків та шапок за оптовими цінами для подальшої роздрібної торгівлі. Широкий асортимент товарів за помірними цінами привабить багато потенційних покупців до її кіоску, сприятиме росту її торгівлі та розширенню бізнесу в майбутньому. Завдяки отриманому прибутку Наталя також планує втілити в життя свою мрію. Навесні вона хоче відкрити два маленьких кіоски з продажу рослин, насіння квітів та добрив, тому що завжди захоплювалася садівництвом.

loans.use: To re-stock her inventory

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children. Her small business selling dishware, kitchenware and pottery is the main source of income for her family. Irina received her first loan from “Nadiya Ukraine” in June, 2002. Currently, she maintains around $7,000 in working capital and her monthly net profit amounts to $500. Irina has a perfect credit history with “Nadiya Ukraine”. She has promptly repaid all loans with no delinquencies. Her neat kiosk with a beautiful array of inventory, her customer-friendly service and exceptional prices has ensured the long-term success of Irina’s business. Irina would like to get a loan for $1,000 to re-stock her inventory. She is planning to increase her supplies of ceramic dish ware, porcelain dinner sets, cutlery, coffee mugs and fancy glasses to attract more potential clients to her vending kiosk. Irina believes her efforts and determination in combination with financial support will eventually help her to achieve her full potential, greater income, and success.

Ірина – одружена, в неї двоє дітей. Вона торгує посудом, кухонним приладдям та керамічними виробами. Цей бізнес є єдиним джерелом прибутку для її родини. Ірина отримала свою першу позику від „Надії України” в червні 2002 року. Зараз в неї приблизно 7000 доларів робочого капіталу, її щомісячний прибуток складає 500 доларів. В Ірини чудова кредитна історія в „Надії України”. Вона вчасно сплатила усі позики без жодних прострочень. Її акуратний кіоск, широкий вибір товарів, ввічливе обслуговування та помірна цінова політика забезпечили стабільний успіх бізнесу Ірини. Ірина хотіла б отримати позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб поповнити асортимент товарів. Вона планує закупити керамічний посуд, порцелянові столові набори та прилади, чашки та скляні вироби для того, щоб придбати більше потенційних клієнтів до свого кіоску. Ірина вважає, що її зусилля та наполегливість у поєднанні з фінансовою підтримкою допоможуть їй реалізувати власний потенціал, отримати більший прибуток та досягти успіху.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Mariya

texts.en:
Mariya is married with two children. She and her husband have a small business selling household items in the local market. Currently, Mariya has about $4,000 of working capital. Her monthly net profit amounts to $1,000. Mariya is a hard-worker. Her diligence and creativity has helped her succeed in business and maintain loyal clientele. Mariya has promptly repaid each of the eleven loans she has received from “Nadiya Ukraine”. Mariya is requesting a loan of $1,000 to re-stock her inventory. She is planning to increase the assortment of plastic trash cans, kitchen accessories, dishware, cookware and other utensils that she offers in her kiosk. Increased selling capacity will not only meet the needs of her clients, but the additional profits generated will meet Mariya’s goals of increasing her income and providing the necessary funds to secure her family’s well-being.

Марія – одружена, в неї двоє дітей. Вони разом з чоловіком почали власний бізнес з продажу побутових товарів на місцевому ринку. Зараз в Марії приблизно 4000 доларів робочого капіталу. Її щомісячний прибуток складає 1000 доларів. Марія – дуже працьовита. Її ретельність у роботі та творчий підхід допомогли їй успішно вести свій бізнесі та зберегти відданих клієнтів. Марія вчасно сплатила усі одинадцять позик, які вона отримала від „Надії України”. Марія просить про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб збільшити асортимент товарів. Вона планує закупити більше пластмасових відер для сміття, кухонного приладдя, посуду та інші необхідні побутові дрібнички для подальшого продажу в своєму кіоску. Збільшення обсягів продажу дасть Марії можливість задовольнити потреби її клієнтів, а отриманий прибуток допоможе Марії досягти поставленої мети та збільшити власні прибутки, забезпечивши добробут своїх рідних.

loans.use: To re-stock inventory

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Georgina is 53 years old, married with 2 children. She sells dry firewood and has been in the business over 4 years. Her main reason for requesting this assistance is to construct a shed to secure her wares from theft and the rains which are coming in the next month or two. This would ensure adequate supplies for her clients during the wet season.

loans.use: Construction of a shed

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Dora is 28 years old and a single parent with 1 child. She prepares for sale a local food made from semi-dry cassava flour and eaten with fried fish. She wants to use the KIVA loan to erect a shed to sell her food. She hopes this will ensure a hygienic environment for her clients. It will also allow her to meet the food safety standards required by city authorities.

loans.use: Construction of a shed

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en: Mariama is 23 years old and single. She was set up by her mother in the selling of household consumables some two years ago. Some of the items include sugar, milk, bagged water, and kenkey. She needs some funding to add other items equally in demand in her area. She is eagerly looking forward to the KIVA assistance to achieve this objective.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kafui

texts.en: Kafui is 40 years old and married with 4 children. She deals mainly in provisions. These include canned foods, eggs, salt, and soap. She took part in the 'TEACH' learning sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION organised in October 2006. She intends to use the KIVA loan to procure other food items for her store.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kojo

texts.en: Kojo is a young man of 25. He sells meat to his community and has been in this business since his junior education. The cost of sheep and goats is increasing day in day out. A greater number of the animals are brought from either Bolgatanga or Bourkina Faso. Kojo therefore seeks to use the KIVA loan to purchase some animals and breed them for sale to his clients as dressed meat.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama is 25 years old and married with 2 children. She supports her husband and their children through her yam sale business. She orders her  goods from fellow traders who go to Techiman for them. Her wish is to be able get enough capital to buy the yams herself at the farmgate. This would allow her to get more profit. She is a beneficiary of KRABAN'S TEACH learning sessions and wants to apply the skills acquired during the training.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kwesi

texts.en: Kwesi is a young man of 24 and single. He is a  refrigerator repairman in his community. The cost of brand-new fridges is beyond the means of many people and therefore they tend to service the old ones for reuse. Parts like motors are very costly yet due to frequent power outages they damage easily and must be replaced. Kwesi is therefore seeking a KIVA loan to purchase some to service his clients' fridges to increase his turnover.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Talamoi

texts.en: Talamoi is not only a tailor for people of all ages and sizes but also an elei designer and printer. She sews for both individuals and groups, like churches and businesses. Her main expenses, apart from her loan repayments, are for paint and designed boards for her prints. Although they are expensive she is not weakened, as she strongly believes that it is worth the effort and the time, especially as her prints are sometimes used on the clothes she sews. She earns three hundred tala a week from sewing and more if her elei prints are sold.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing marchine, materials, needles, and overlock thread.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: As people of the sea, seafood is favored by many people. Ana is one of many people that fish for a living. Her husband helps her out with the hard part  of the work, which is getting the sea urchins and fish. The seafood is sold on the roadside to people going to and from town to the rural areas. Sometimes it is bought by people going back to their country of residence. If her sales are good for the day, she earns one hundred and twenty tala. That is then used to pay for family needs and wants and most importantly to update her payments with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear and pay school fees.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Fali

texts.en: Fali does not want to waste any working day of the week. From Monday to Friday, she spends and manages her time well.  She goes out to fish and then sells her seafood on the roadside. The income of two hundred tala daily makes it possible for her to put her children in school, pay for family obligations, and repay her debts to SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase fishing gear (spears, goggles, bottles) and pay for school fees.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Asai

texts.en: Asai enjoys making umu to sell to the public.  She sells taro, breadfruit, bananas, luau with turkey tails, herring in coconut cream and the normal luau.  Her stall opens on Monday, Tuesday and Friday only.  Asai earns $400 but only $80 is profit.  This money is used to send her children to school, pay for family needs and of course her loan repayments.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase sacks of taro, bananas, coconuts, breadfruit, luau, and tauaga.   It will also finance school fees and home improvement.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Asuisui

texts.en: Taro in coconut cream is one of people's old time favorites. Asuisui sells this as well as Samoan cocoa  or niu to go along with it, depending on the buyer’s choice.  Three people work for Asuisui.  Her weekends are used to prepare the necessary ingredients for the stall like getting taro from the plantations, husking nuts and so on.  After all debts have been paid for she makes a profit $300.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of taro, bananas, coconuts and yams. The loan will also purchase wood, a gas stove as well as finance school fees and home improvement.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Ruta

texts.en: Ruta of Alafua makes a beautiful fruit salad which she sells in front of one of the dairies near her home. She is the only one selling vi salad.  Alternatively, she sometimes also makes taro in coconut cream or oka to raise her revenues.  She makes a profit of $250 daily.  This money is used to improve her family’s living standard and conditions as well as pay off her loan from SPBD.

loans.use: The money will go towards purchasing a pot, peeler, bowl, knife, vi, coconuts, and fresh fish.  The loan will also pay for school fees and home improvement.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Fiavae

texts.en: Vaitele has a large population.  Fiavae is from Vaitele and sews for a living. Most of her clients are neighbors but some are from other areas.  She is a hard worker and earns $300 of profit in a week.  She is happy as she can financially support her family and can stand on her own two feet without relying on her family for money.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine, needles, material, zippers, cement, timber, and nails.

loans.name: Lalotoga

texts.en: It is a Lalotogas passion to make ice cakes and boiled eggs to sell.  She makes 50 ice cakes and 5 dozen eggs each day.  The ice cakes are sold in nearby stores and she makes her rounds selling the eggs.  It is also very fortunate for her that her husband works for Samoatel. He supports her by helping her prepare the ice cakes whenever he is available. Lalotoga makes $250 in profit, which helps her pay back the loan from SPBD and meet her family commitments.

loans.use: The loan will go towards purchasing cool aid, plastic cups, eggs, snacks, and ice pops.  She also needs to buy a pot and tray.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Nurhandayani

texts.en:
Nurhandayani, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $125. She runs a business that sells woven mat to families in her village on monthly installment payment plans. With this loan she will be able to purchase more woven mats. A mat costs IDR50,000 which she will sell under this plan at IDR100,000. Repayments will be made monthly.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Selling mats

loans.name: Rohati

texts.en:
Rohati, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $150. Prior to becoming a member of MBK she was selling fried food only. However, after becoming a member of MBK and on attaining this loan, she will be able to operate a store with more comprehensive items and also raise chickens. Revenue of IDR70.000 will generate income of IDR40,000 while she sell the chicken once a month. 1 kilogram (about 2.2 pound) is sold for IDR8,000. She easily qualifies as a member of MBK through her ability to finance the purchase of a motorcycle from her earnings.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: General store

loans.name: Enung

texts.en:
Enung is member of MBK who has requested a third loan for US$ 150. She has been running her business for long time. The loan that she requested from MBK will be used to buy the inventory for her store. Her income can reach US$ 18 with a profit of US$ 1.20 per day.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by C. Patriawan, Kiva volunteer

loans.use: general store

loans.name: Samani

texts.en:
Samani, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $150. She is expanding her duck breeding business. Prior to becoming a member of MBK, she is only able to raise 200 ducks but with this loan she is able to increase her farm to 800 ducks. Apart from ducks, Samani also raise 15 goats. Every alternate day, Samani sells 600 duck eggs at IDR700 each.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Duck breeding

loans.name: Wati

texts.en:
Wati, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $100. Wati is happy to be a member of MBK because prior to that she is unable to improve her family’s economic status. Currently, Wati sells oil and farms. Therefore, a portion of this loan will be used to purchase more oil while the rest to purchase fertilizer, seeds, and pesticides. Revenue received from the sale of oil amount to IDR50,000 daily with a profit of IDR10,000. Currently, there is no revenue from farming as they are not due for harvest yet.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Sells oil

loans.name: Ulfah

texts.en:
Ulfah is member of MBK who has requested a third loan for US$ 100. Ulfah is selling salad and snacks in small food stall near her village's school. She used to borrow the money from the local bank that has very high interest and very short payment terms (1 month), but she is very thankful now because in addition to strengthening her business, she could also now save some money and put her child into school. The loan that she requested from MBK will be used for her general food stalls inventory and some portion will be used to grow and farm chicken, goats and fish. In one day she could receive an income of US$ 8 while making profit of US$ 1.10.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by C. Patriawan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Food and Snacks

loans.name: Sanah

texts.en:
Sanah, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $150. Sanah and her husband have been selling fried food. Sanah and her husband can generate a daily revenue of IDR150,000 with a profit of IDR30,000. Currently, Sanah is able to secure credit terms for the purchase of a motorcycle.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Selling fried food

loans.name: Emi

texts.en:
Emi, a member of MBK, is requesting for a loan of $100. Emi and her husband have been in selling coconut milk rice, cooked rice in banana leaf, iced drinks and light snacks. The entire loan from MBK will be used for supplies for the store. The daily revenue amount to IDR80,000 with a profit of IDR40,000. Currently, Emi is reinvesting the profits from her store by purchasing goats and chickens.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Pheng Tan, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Sells coconut milk rice

loans.name: Ati

texts.en:
Ati is a member of MBK who has requested her third loan of $100. She became a member to raise some working capital so she can help her family's economy. Ati owns a vegetable farm. The loan will be used to purchase seeds, fertilizers and crop protection agents. Ati harvests her crops once every 25 days, generates revenue of IDR 500,000 and profits IDR 300,000 from it

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: to grow vegetable

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
O. began his charcoal sales business with $150.  He has managed his business well, and is married with one child. A loan will enable him to buy the charcoal in bulk and save on transport.

He will use his profits to open a business for his wife and save for the future.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock

loans.name: Enjah

texts.en:
Enjah is a member of MBK who has requested her third loan of $100. Enjah and her husband own a farm and grow vegetable such as spinach, water spinach and lemon basil. Enjah began her business since she received some loan from MBK. Now she can help support her family. She harvests her crops once every 25 days, generates revenue of IDR 600,000 and profits IDR 400,000 from it

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To grow vegetable

loans.name: Suryati

texts.en:
Suryati is a member of MBK who has requested her third loan of $100. She initially used her first loan to sell soap and failed. She eventually switched to growing vegetable crops and has been more succesful. From the sales of vegetable twice a month, Suryati can earn IDR 300,000 of profit, which is used to send her child to school.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

Suryati merupakan anggota MBK yang telah mendapatkan pinjaman ketiga sebesar $80. Pinjaman pertama pernah dia gunakan untuk berdagang sabun tetapi tidak berhasil, akhirnya dia beralih profesi menjadi petani sayur-sayuran dan sekarang cukup berhasil. Dari hasil penjualan sayur-sayuran, yang dilakukan 2x sebulan, Suryati bisa mendapatkan keuntungan sebesar Rp. 300,000. Dari keuntungan tersebut, Suryati bisa menyekolahkan anaknya.

loans.use: To grow Vegetable

loans.name: Suarti

texts.en:
Suarti is a member of MBK who has requested her third loan of $100. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase merchandise for her store and the rest will be used to help her husband's farm. In a day Suarti can generate IDR 150,000 of revenue with IDR 10,000 of profit, from which she can send her children to school.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: Warung

loans.name: Ombiyah

texts.en:
Ombiyah is a member of MBK who has requested her second loan of $100. Selling variety of fried delicacies is her daily business. She sells her food in front of one of the schools in her village. Before becoming a member of MBK, she had to borrow money to buy ingredients, which had to be repaid the following afternoon. But now Ombiyah has secured her own capital, and can buy more ingredients so as to increase her income.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients for her fried delicacies

loans.name: Simih

texts.en:
Simah is a widow with four children. Her oldest son Pudin, 25 years old, has his own business of making bricks. She is a member of MBK who has requested her second loan of $100. Simah has been running her general store business long before becoming a member of MBK. A portion of the loan will be used to purchase merchandise for her store, while the rest will be used for her son's business. In a day Simah can generate IDR 70,000 of sales with IDR 10,000 of profit.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Rohamah

texts.en: Rohamah is married with two children ages 21 and 9. Having a small store that provides various snacks and household goods is Rohamah’s business. She has requested her second loan from MBK for $75. This loan will be used for buying more goods for her store. The profit earned from her store is primarily used to send her children to school.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Francis

texts.en:
Francis has been selling charcoal since 1986, a business he began with $100 capital. Since then he has grown from selling charcoal retail to being a wholesale provider. He has managed to take care of his family with this business.

He plans to use his loan to further increase his stock so he can supply more of the many customers who buy charcoal on a daily basis.

He is married and has seven children who are going to school. He will us the profit to pay for school fees and for family needs.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock

loans.name: Marwah

texts.en:
Marwah has a 19 years old child. She is a member of MBK who has requested her second loan of $100. The loan will be used primarily to purchase merchandise for her store while, due to her illness, a small portion will be set aside for her medication. Her daily revenue is IDR 200,000 with IDR 20,000 of profit.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Arliadi Mahadi, Kiva Volunteer.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her general store

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela started her general store in 2005 with $200 capital supplied by her previous employer. She is married and has four children. She is educated to level 8.

She will use her loan to increase the variety of goods she sells and take advantage of more customer demands. 

She will use her profits to finish the house her family has begun to build.

loans.use: Purchase additional stock for her business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Rael has owned and operated her business since 1980. She received a loan from KREP, which boosted her business and which she successfully repaid. She is married and has 6 children, two of which are still in school.

She will use her loan to diversify her business and attract more clients.

She will save her profits for a safety net, so that when an emergency occurs, she doesn't have to use business capital.

loans.use: To add stock in the business.

loans.name: Ann

texts.en:
Ann has been selling second-hand clothes since 1990, and due to her successful management, the business has been able to sustain her family. She is educated to level 5 and is married with three children.

She will use her loan to buy clothes in bales, which will be more profitable for her retail sales.

She will put her profits back into the business so it will continue to grow.

loans.use: Purchase stock to build business

loans.name: Tatyana

texts.en:
Tatyana is married and has two grown daughters. After graduating from a college of commerce, she started working as a market vendor. Today she runs her own business selling scarves and swimwear in the central city market. Presently, Tatyana has about $1,000 of working capital. Her monthly profit amounts to $150-200. Tatyana has been in this trade for five years now. There are very few other businesses selling similar items in the market where Tatyana has her kiosk. Because of this, customer demand continues to grow all the time. Tatyana has established a reputation as an entrepreneur of integrity. She has repaid every loan she has received from “Nadiya Ukraine” without any defaults. Tatyana is requesting a loan for $800 to re-stock her inventory before the spring/summer season. She is planning to purchase bright silk, chiffon and satin scarves, soft shawls and one and two piece swimsuits. Compelling prices and a wide range of fashion choices to suit every taste and lifestyle will attract many new clients to Tatyana’s business. An increase in sales will help her generate more profit and pay for her daughter’s college tuition.

Тетяна – одружена, в неї двоє дорослих дітей. Після закінчення технікуму Радянської Торгівлі, вона почала торгувати на центральному міському ринку. Зараз вона займається продажем шарфів, парео, купальників та плавок. Зараз в Тетяни приблизно 1000 доларів робочого капіталу. Її щомісячний прибуток складає 150-200 доларів. Тетяна займається цією торгівлею вже 5 років. На ринку, де розташований кіоск Тетяни, лише декілька інших підприємців займаються цим бізнесом. Саме тому постійно зростає попит з боку споживачів. В Тетяни склалася репутація чесного підприємця. Вона сплатила усі позики, які отримала в „Надії України” без жодних прострочень. Вона просить про позику в 800 доларів для того, щоб розширити асортимент товарів напередодні весняного/літнього періоду. Вона планує закупити яскраві шовкові, шифонові та атласні шарфи, м’які шалі, високоякісні парео, різні купальники. Помірні ціни та широкий вибір модних новинок задовольнять будь-який смак та приваблять багато нових клієнтів до кіоску Тетяни. Збільшення обсягів продажу допоможе їй отримати додатковий прибуток та заплатити за навчання сина в університеті.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Nikolai

texts.en:
Nikolai is divorced with one child. He is a taxi driver and has been in business for five years. Driving is his only source of income. Sometimes he ends up working 24 hours a day to provide for himself and his family. Presently, he makes around $30-40 per day. Nikolai is a focused, hard-worker. He started his first business selling groceries in the market. However, after his divorce and changing family situation, Nikolai decided to work in a different business sphere and began driving a taxi. The nine loans that Nikolai has received from “Nadiya Ukraine” have helped him to expand his business. Nikolai is requesting a loan of $600 to help buy a newer car with improved diesel efficiency that will be both quieter and smoother running. A reliable vehicle operating on bio methane fuel, with eco-friendly fuel consumption, good emissions characteristics and better refinement will not only help Nikolai reduce his overhead costs, but will also lessen the amount of pollution produced and will increase the resource-saving capability of his vehicle. Nikolai is also getting married in May, 2007. He is planning to use income generated by his business to cover some of the expenses of his wedding.

Микола – розлучений, в нього одна дитина. Він – водій таксі, займається цим бізнесом 5 років. Це єдине джерело прибутку для його родини. Іноді він працює по 24 години на добу для того, щоб забезпечувати власну родину. Зараз Микола заробляє приблизно 30-40 доларів. Микола – дуже цілеспрямований та працьовитий. Він починав з торгівлі харчами на ринку. Однак, після розлучення його сімейна ситуація кардинально змінилася. Отже, Микола вирішив почати працювати в іншій сфері та став водієм. Дев’ять позик, які Микола отримав від „Надії України”, допомогли йому розширити власний бізнес. Микола просить про позику в 600 доларів для того, щоб купити новіше авто з кращим дизельним мотором, що робить пересування тихішим та приємнішим. Надійне авто, яке працюватиме на стиснутому метані, що знизить викиди в атмосферу, та більш якісною системою очищення не тільки допоможе Миколі знизити витрати, але й допоможе зменшити масштаби забруднення та покращити ресурсномісткі показники його автомобіля. Микола одружується в травні 2007 року. Він планує використати отриманий від бізнесу прибуток для того, щоб оплатити весільні витрати.

loans.use: To buy a newer vehicle

loans.name: Bunchy

texts.en:
S. Bunchy and Mao Heng have been married for a long time. They are 60 years old and had six children. Nowadays, they are living with their four children and running a small grocery shop near their house. They sell for around 40,000 Riel (10 USD) everyday and get a profit of around 10,000 Riel (2.5 USD). Their daughter is working at a textile factory and gets a salary of 15 USD per month to support their family.
Both of them applied for the loan of 600 USD to expand and enlarge their shop which will cost about 400 USD and use the remaining 200 USD to buy a bed and additional foods for selling to people around their house every evening.
After they got the loan to invest their business they hope they will increase income and have it jump up to 6 USD per day.
In the future when they finish this cycle they hope take a new loan to enlarge their business more and repair their house also.

loans.use: Repair and enlarge their shop

payments.comment: Congratulations to Bunchy Sarith who closed her loan early! Thank you making this loan possible. We appreciate your ongoing support of poor Cambodian entrepreneurs and our clients. Best regards, Jordyan Edmiston, Kiva Fellow & the entire CREDIT MFI team

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is 30 years old and is married with 4 children. Monica also takes care of her brother and sister, aged 14 and 16 years respectively, since her parents are not in a position to support them because of their old age. They live within the Kibera slums of Nairobi.

Monica used to braid ladies hair at different salons where she was be paid on commission. She operated in this manner for six months, after which she was luckily employed at a particular salon after having done exemplary work on several occasions. Having gained experience for two years, Monica decided to start her own business in 2000 after saving Ksh 3,000.00 ($43) through a village merry-go-round group for women. The determination to open a salon led her to purchase a blowdryer and some chairs. In 2003, Monica bought a second hand hairdryer and over the years her clients have doubled, as has the demand. 

Monica is therefore kindly asking for a loan of $175 so that she can purchase a new hairdryer and blowdryer. She intends to pay back the loan within a period of 8 – 14 months. The additional equipment will enable her to offer quick and efficient service to her royal customers. They will also enhance the expansion for her business. She will need assistance and thereby create job opportunities by employing additional staff to help her cope with the growing demand.

At the same time, Monica has been approached by the village elders to offer training to a growing number of teenage mothers who are interested in hairdressing and beauty courses.  They, in turn, can gain a form of employment in the future through their skills.  Her vision is for the future to look brighter for the slum dwellers of Kibera.

loans.use: To purchase one hairdryer and one blowdryer.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph Otieno O. is a 25-year-old man. He is married with two children and lives within the Kibera slums of Nairobi. Apart from his wife and two children, Joseph takes care of nine orphans too. Four children from his brother and five from his sister, who are both victims of the AIDS pandemic.

Joseph earns his livelihood by operating a salon and barbershop in Raila, a small village within the Kibera slums. It has been in operation for the last 7 years. Joseph received hair dressing skills from his father’s salon and barbershop in Ahero, in the Western part of Kenya, where he worked for 2 years. He would blow dry (straightening) and perm (chemical application for straightening) ladies’ hair and give haircuts to men. Joseph pooled his savings of Ksh 2,000.00 ($29) with his father’s kind donation of 3,000.00 ($43) to rent a room, buy a blowdryer and a shaving machine. He says he is happy seeing his clients beam with joy after doing their hair.

Joseph’s fame in Kibera is known and right now he is turning away a good number of his clients because the hairdryer and blowdryer he has cannot meet the growing demand of his many customers. Therefore Joseph is requesting a loan of $175, to be repaid within 8 months, which he will use to buy a hairdryer and a blowdryer. Both of these tools will translate into more income for his business. This will in turn create job opportunities for more people, therefore alleviating poverty within his community.

loans.use: To purchase one hairdryer and one blowdryer.

loans.name: Gonçalves

texts.en:
Gonçalves S. is 52 years old and originally from Zambézia. Growing up, his parents were big cattle raisers and provided a very good financial situation, which gave him the opportunity to study. Since 1999 he has been raising chickens. He doesn’t have a store but supplies the local Market directly from his home. He learned about Hluvuku at the end of 2006 through some neighbors who are small business owners and he became interested in getting a loan for himself. Currently his business of raising chickens is going well, but the number of chicks produced is very small given his financial limitations. He employs one sales person and also counts on support from his wife. The business of selling chickens is the primary source of income for the family’s survival. With a loan of 25,000MT he plans to increase the volume of the business by increasing the number of chicks produced which will increase his income capacity. His business has a large impact on his community. Besides providing employment, the community benefits from the animal protein sold at affordable prices. With the growth of his business, he hopes to build a larger chicken farm, which would also create more job opportunities in the area.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Gonçalves S. de 52 anos de idade, natural de Zambézia, cresceu sob responsabilidade dos seus Pais, a situação financeira estava muito bem eram grandes criadores de gado bovino com boa oportunidades para estudar. Desde o ano de 1999 vem assumindo na integração a gestão de negócio criando frangos, não possui nenhum estabelecimento de negócio apenas tem vendido na sua casa por vez no Mercado. Teve conhecimento da Hluvuku nos finais de 2006, através dos vizinhos micro empresários, sendo empreendedor desde então interessou-se pelo empréstimo. Actualmente a sua actividade de criação de frangos está num ritmo razoável, embora as quantidades de pintos que consegue adquirir são tão insignificantes, devido a limitações financeiras. Providencia emprego para uma pessoa, cuja função é das vendas e também conta com ajuda da esposa. O negocio de venda de frangos é a principal fonte de sobrevivência da família. Com o empréstimo de 25.000,00 MT pretende aumentar o volume de negócio, acrescentado o número de pintos o que permitirá o aumento dos rendimentos. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na sua comunidade porque para alem de providenciar emprego, a comunidade beneficia-se de proteína animal a preços acessíveis. Com o crescimento do negocio, tenciona construir um novo aviário com maior capacidade e criar mais oportunidades de emprego na zona.

loans.use: To raise more chickens

payments.comment: Goncalves had successfully made 2 payments in May and finished his first loan with Kiva! He would like to personally thank Kiva and especially all his lenders for the support given to his business.

loans.name: França

texts.en:
França Valente C. is 56 years old and originally from Chokwé, in the Gaza Province. In 1980 he took over his family’s agricultural business, which had always supported them. He owns roughly 10 hectares. He leaned of HLUVIKU-ADSEMA through a conversation with friends in August 2006 and came to request a loan to purchase more farmland. He hopes that the loan will help her business reach a new level. His main crop is cabbage, which is sold in Boane and Maputo. Currently his business is not going well. There is a drought in the south of Mozambique and the river waters are well below normal. Consequently he has to use a lot of fuel to work the irrigation pump. His business creates jobs for five people, including himself. The profits from his business cover his daughter’s school expenses and allow his to save a little. He plans to purchase additional land in a neighboring district.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

França Valente C. de 56 anos de idade, natural de Chokwé, Província de Gaza, cresceu na responsabilidade dos Pais. Desde 1980 vem assumindo na integra a gestão de negócio da família, agricultura, que sempre foi a base de sobrevivência. Possui uma área com cerca de 10 ha. A partir de Agosto de 2006 em conversa com os amigos teve conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA, tendo recorrido a esta para solicitar empréstimo para ampliar sua área de cultivo. Espera com empréstimo conhecer outra dinâmica da sua actividade, cuja principal cultura é o repolho que por sua vez é comercializada no distrito de Boane e Cidade do Maputo. Actualmente o seu negócio não está num bom ritmo, pois com a seca que se verifica na zona sul de Moçambique o rio umbeluzi apresenta caudal muito abaixo do normal, situação que lhe obriga a despender muito combustível para rega. A actividade criou postos de trabalho para cinco pessoas, incluindo ele próprio. Com os rendimentos do negócio suporta as despesas de escola da filha e também consegue fazer pequenas poupanças. O seu plano de crescimento preconiza negociar outra propriedade num distrito vizinho.

loans.use: To increase production of crops

loans.name: Mariana

texts.en:
Mariana Sarmento M. is 56 years old and is originally from Maputo. Her parents’ financial position allowed her to study through the 4th grade, only until her father abandoned the family. Her mother was unemployed so she had to work at a clothing sweatshop to help support her mother and six siblings. She is now married and has 5 children. When her fifth child was just a year old her husband died and she was forced to take over his business, which she continues today. She learned about HLUVUVU-ADSEMA through her neighbors and applied for a loan to grow her business. Currently her business is going well. In addition to selling basic household goods she has started a small Restaurant and Bar. The income from her business supports her family and pays the salary of 2 employees. With her savings she will build a living room for her home and buy a car to transport goods for her store. With the loan for 30,000MT she hopes to increase her stock volume to avoid constant and almost daily trips to Maputo city for supplies, a distance of 35K from Mafuiane, which will also lower her transportation costs. Her business has a large impact on the community. In addition to providing employment for herself and two others, she brings products closer to the residents of Aldeia de Mafuiane and every year she provides a free lunch on Children’s Day to all the kids in Aldeia.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Mariana Sarmento M. de 56 anos de idade, natural de Cidade de Maputo Província de Maputo, cresceu sob a responsabilidade dos Pais. A situação financeira da família sou lhe permitiu estudar até 4º classe, depois seu Pai abandonou a família e a sua Mãe era desempregada, quando começou a trabalhar numa Empresa de Fábrica de Vestuário para sustentar a sua Mãe e os seus irmãos, veio a casar e teve cinco (5) filhos e quando o seu quinto filho tinha apenas 1 ano o seu marido faleceu, foi quando então começou a dedicar-se a um negócio que dele sobrevive até hoje. Através da vizinhas teve o conhecimento da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA e ficou interessada em obter um empréstimo para ampliar o seu negócio. O seu negócio encontra-se neste momento num bom ritmo porque alem de vender produtos de primeira necessidade introduziu agora serviço de Restaurante e Bar. Com o rendimento da mesma actividade suporta as despesas familiares e paga salário aos seus 2 empregado. Com as poupanças do negocio esta a construir uma moradia familiar e para um futuro breve tenciona comprar uma viatura para transporte de mercadoria da loja. Com o empréstimo de 30.000,00 MT pretende aumentar o volume de mercadoria de forma a evitar viagens constantes e quase diárias a cidade de Maputo para fazer compras, pois dista 35 Kms de Mafuiane, reduzindo assim os custos de transporte. A sua actividade tem um maior impacto na comunidade porque para alem de providenciar emprego a ela própria e dois jovens, coloca o produto mais próximo da População da Aldeia de Mafuiane e anualmente oferece lanche gratuito no dia da criança para todos os meninos da aldeia.

loans.use: To increase the stocks in her shop

loans.name: Júlia

texts.en:
Julia Ernesto Chambas is 33 years old and originally from Boane, in Maputo province. She is single and a mother of 5 children. Because her father died when she was young, she never had the opportunity to study. She has been running her business since she was a teenager and has a small store next to the Boane market. At the end of 2006 friends and neighbors introduced her to Hluvuki-Adsema and she requested her first loan, a service she had never had the opportunity to use before. She hopes to reach a new level in her business. With a loan for 13,000MT she plans to strengthen her business by supplying a greater variety of clothing for her customers in Boane. The profits from her business support her family’s basic needs, including medical expenses and her children’s education. Her business has a large impact on the community. She generates employment for herself and others, and makes clothing available at affordable prices.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva volunteer Julie Lerch

Julia Ernesto C. de 33 anos de idade, natural de Boane, província de Maputo, solteira e mãe de 5 filhos. Devido ao falecimento do pai, não teve oportunidades para estudar.Vem assumindo o seu negocio desde adolescente e possui um pequeno estabelecimento comercial ao lado do mercado de Boane. Nos finais de 2006, por indicação de amigas e vizinhas, soube da existência da Hluvuku-Adsema tendo aproximado e solicitado o primeiro empréstimo numa instituição, pois oportunidade de ter um serviço financeiro formal nunca teve. Espera conhecer uma nova dinâmica na sua actividade. Com empréstimo de 13.000,00 MT pretende reforçar o seu negocio de forma a fornecer variedades de roupa aos clientes de Boane. Com os rendimentos do seu negocio suporta as despesas básicas da família, incluindo assistência medica e medicamentosa e educação dos seus filhos. A sua actividade tem um impacto maior na comunidade pois para alem de providenciar emprego para ela própria e outra pessoa, coloca artigos de roupa mais perto do cliente à preços acessíveis. Tem como perspectiva fazer crescer o negócio, educar os filhos até níveis superior e transformar-se numa empresária de sucesso.

loans.use: To increase stock of clothes in her shop

loans.name: Laurinda

texts.en:
Laurinda João M. is 37 years old, originally from Boane, a mother of three and a widow. Her family’s financial condition did not allow her to study past the 5th grade. She had a traditional marriage, but became an early widow and had to take over the business left by her husband. She heard about HLUVUKU-ADSEMA and applied for a loan to grow her business. With a loan for 10,000MT she plans to increase her stock volume to meet the needs of her customers and increase her income. Her business has a large impact on the community. She creates her own employment and income to support the basic needs of her three fatherless children and her grandson. In addition, she provides a useful service to her community.

Translated from Portuguese by Kiva Volunteer Julie Lerch

Laurinda João M. de 37 anos de idade, natural de Boane, mãe de três filhos, viúva, as condições de vida não lhe permitiram estudar para alem de 5º classe, teve um casamento tradicional precoce, ficou viúva muito cedo e assumiu o negócio deixado pelo Marido. Quando soube da existência da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA pela necessidade de serviços de crédito, aproximou-se e solicitou um empréstimo para ampliar o seu negócio. Com o empréstimo de 10.000,00 MT (dez mil meticais ) pretende aumentar o stock em produtos, de modo a responder as necessidades dos clientes e consequentemente aumentar os rendimentos. A sua actividade tem um grande impacto, pois providencia emprego para ela própria, cuja fonte de rendimento suporta as necessidades básicas dos seus três filhos órfãos de Pai e do seu neto, para além de prestar um serviço útil para sua comunidade.

loans.use: To increase stock volume in her shop

loans.name: Francisco

texts.en:
Mr. O. owns a business that offers printing and copying services, a field he has worked in for more than 20 years. He is a married father of 4 children. Through Prisma, he plans to use the loan money to buy materials like ink, paper, printer parts, etc. so that his company can fill customer orders. This economic support will help him increase income and afford his family a more comfortable life.

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. O. es propietario de una imprenta y labora en este campo desde hace más de 20 años. Es casado y padre de 4 hijos, el dinero que le pueda proporcionar Prisma lo utilizaría en la compra de materiales como Tinta, papelería, repuestos para sus impresoras, etc. para poder cubrir los pedidos de sus clientes. Este apoyo económico le permitirá incrementar sus ingresos y brindar más comodidad a sus familiares.

loans.use: To buy materials in order to fill customer orders.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Moevao

texts.en: Moevao has a multi-variety shop.  She sells vegetables, handicrafts, fruit and brooms.  Depending on sales, she makes $70 in profit after meeting all of her other expenses.  Like the other women,  Moevao  saves this money for the future especially for unforseen circumstances.  She is very thankful to SPBD in making her dreams come true as she has many talents, not only as a gardener but as a cook and  creator of new handicrafts.

loans.use: To purchase soda, snacks, soaps, mutton flaps, turkey tails, and chicken for her shop.

loans.name: Ake

texts.en: Ake, with help from her husband, owns a convenience shop in her village of Vaitele.  The income from the shop is used for multiple reasons. Her first priority are her payments, as she wants to continue working with SPBD. She also spends money on improving her home as it is getting old and in need of renovations.

loans.use: To purchase flaps, turkey tails, chicken, soda, milk, soaps, powder cement and timber.

loans.name: Siuta

texts.en: Unlike many people in town, Siuta of Vaitele does not need to go to the market for root crops or local produce.  She owns her own plantation and also has a BBQ stand.  At the stand, she sells both BBQ and fruits that she has grown on the plantation.  Additionally her husband sells his catch at the fish market.  When all her expenses are paid for, she saves half of her $150. The other half is spent on her children and family.  Her husbands earnings are separate from hers and all of it is deposited in the bank for the future.

loans.use: To purchase a BBQ stove, mutton flap, chicken, turkey tails, cement and timber.

loans.name: Fiti

texts.en: Fiti owns a big plantation, which not only has taros and bananas but also vegetables such as pumpkins, eggplant, tomatoes and so forth. The sales earn her a profit of three hundred tala.  This money is used for a number of purposes including family occasions and church donations. But most of it is saved as Fiti wants to expand her business to be a big commercial supplier of root crops and vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, a rake, cabbage (seeds), a wheelbarrow, and plastic bags for home improvement

loans.name: Falai

texts.en: Falai takes her three children to school,and this is where her sausage sizzle stall operates. The sausages easily run out as these are their favourites. Fifty tala each day is her target revenue thus in a week she earns two hundred and fifty tala. Falai is excited with how business is going and is not ready to give up even if her loan is paid off she is determined to continue on her sausage sizzles.

loans.use: To purchase sausages, cooking oil, fry, gas stove, Foil, tomato sauce, school fees.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Mooui

texts.en: Mooui A. is a 53 year old married woman who has nine children. She joined SPBD in 2000 and has been a faithful and pleasant member to the program. She received her first loan from SPBD to start her sewing business back in 2000 and the business is very successful. She then received a second loan to start a grocery shop which is also now very successful. Her third, fourth and fifth loans were to re-stock her grocery shop to help maintain her customer base. She still needs more help from the program to expand her grocery shop so she can cater to the increased demand.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock for her grocery shop.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Pepe

texts.en: Pepe L. is a 35 year old married woman who has five children. She is a member of the Utulaelae Centre. She was jobless before joining the SPBD program. The loans from SPBD program helped her develop her taro plantation, from which she earns around $200-$300 tala per week from selling 2-3 sacks of taro. Her intention is to get more loans from the SPBD program in order to establish a cattle farm.  She hopes to expand her house a bit more and to assist her family financially.

loans.use: to purchase cattle and fencing materials to establish a cattle farm

loans.name: Rita

texts.en: Rita F. is a 37 year old mother of three and currently a member of the Lalomanu Centre. Rita runs a beach resort which she set up in 2004 with financial assistance from the South Pacific Business Development. Rita was unemployed before she joined the program and depended on overseas families for her financial development. Rita earns $500-800 a week and caters to tourists that come to rural coastal areas to experience the Samoan way of life.  Rita is looking forward to receive another loan from SPBD in order to assist her family financially.

loans.use: To build two additional beach cottages (fale) to expand her resort business.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Seaga

texts.en: Seaga is a 54 year old mother of six. She is the centre chief of the Utulaelae Centre. Before joining SPBD, she was not employed and depended heavily on relatives and overseas remittances for survival. Her first, second and third loans were used to expand her family’s taro plantation. Seaga earns $300 a week but she still needs more funds for family development and home improvement.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, chemicals and fungicides for her taro farm.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Tulagamua

texts.en: Tulagamua F. is a married woman who has 2 children. She is 43 years of age. She is a member of the Utulaelae Centre. She is currently on her fourth loan. Her first loan was used to establish her banana chip shop.  The second, third and fourth loan were used to set up a cattle farm. Mrs. F. was jobless and had no businesses before she joined SPBD. With the help of SPBD she now owns several businesses. She requests further loans to purchase additional cattle and expand her plantation business.

loans.use: to purchase additional cattle

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Venise

texts.en: Venise S. is a 43 year old married woman with 3 children.  She is from the Vavau B Center. She was given three loans from the SPBD Program for her taro plantation and fishing business. Before joining SPBD she relied on her overseas relatives for financial support. Now she earns more than 300 a week from her taro plantation and fishing business. She intends to expand her taro plantation and plant other crops like bananas and vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, pesticides and fungicides

loans.name: Mufliha

texts.en: Mufliha is a mother of four children and has a grand-daughter, Salsabila.  She owns a small grocery shop that sells household goods like cooking oil, wheat, and salted fish.  She will use her loan to buy more goods for her shop.  She also wants to use some of the money to send one of her daughters to a sewing course like one of her sisters did.  Once her daughter has finished the sewing course, she can work in a garment factory.  Her salary would help Mufliha and the family.  The grocery shop is Mufliha’s only livelihood as her husband does not have permanent work.  Mufliha really wants to earn more money for her children’s education as her third child had to stop her education after elementary school.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory for store

loans.name: Linh

texts.en:
Linh's husband has died, and she must support her 4 children. Unfortunately the youngest one, Nghia, just 7, is mentally retarded. Trung, the eldest, stopped going to school to take care for his little brother.

Linh is running a small shop with a daily profit of almost 1$. When she can she also makes bamboo baskets, which brings an additional 70 cents/day.

loans.use: 50$ to increase the capital of her little shop

loans.name: Rohayati

texts.en: Rohayati sells fried bananas, cooked snacks, and assorted fruits such as apples, oranges, and lychees.  She used to sell them in front of her house on small tables. Howeber it was not generating enough income, so she decided to sell them through small shops nearby.  She very much wants to earn more income by using the loan to buy more inventory goods and open a small booth on the side of the road. Her husband can only manage to occasionally find temporary work as an unskilled construction worker.

loans.use: Purchase additional inventory, and to open her own kiosk

loans.name: Dung

texts.en:
Dung and her husband Truyên have a small shop selling mainly vegetables, as their only source of income. They own no land at all except the 17 m2 of their little house and shop.

They have children between 16 and 22, all students and education is very expensive in Vietnam. But their present income is only $10 per person/month.

With the loan they will open a small booth at the market.

loans.use: Loan to increase the capital of their shop

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is married and has five children. She has been trained by Rafode in business management and loan use, and has managed this business for the last three years.

Given the loan, she plans to diversify her business by stocking fresh milk. Therefore the capital will be used to buy a cooler and stock. The profits will be used to educate her children and finish building her house.

loans.use: Purchase of additional stock.

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two children. She always wanted to be an entrepreneur and saw many opportunities everywhere she looked. Irina decided on a small business selling clothing and footwear for women and today she runs a vending kiosk in one of the local markets. Currently, Irina has about $4,000 of working capital in her business and she makes about $600 a month in net profit. Irina is very cheery and optimistic. Her radiant smile and ability to make her clients feel welcome at her kiosk attracts many potential customers and helps her business grow. Irina has been a client with “Nadiya Ukraine” since 2002. Irina is requesting a loan for $1,000 to open a new vending facility where she would like to begin selling shoes. She is planning to rent a facility, do all the necessary remodeling and purchase a variety of shoes, sneakers and sandals in preparation for the spring season. Irina’s business and marketing abilities in combination with financial assistance will help her to get this new venture off the ground and further increase her success and income.

Ірина – одружена, в неї двоє дітей. Вона завжди хотіла бути підприємцем, вміла бачити можливості для цього навколо. Ірина вирішила відкрити власний бізнес з продажу жіночого одягу та взуття. Зараз в неї є торгівельна точка на одному з місцевих ринків. В Ірини приблизно 4000 доларів робочого капіталу, щомісяця вона заробляє приблизно 600 доларів чистого прибутку. Ірина - дуже жвава та оптимістична. Її промениста посмішка та привітна вдача приваблюють багато потенційних покупців до її кіоску, що, в свою чергу, сприяє росту її бізнесу. Ірина співпрацює з „Надією України” з 2002 року. Ірина просить про позику в 1000 доларів для того, щоб відкрити нову торгівельну точку з продажу взуття. Вона планує орендувати приміщення, зробити необхідний ремонт та закупити різноманітне взуття, а саме, кеди та босоніжки напередодні весняного періоду. Досвід Ірини в сфері бізнесу та маркетингу у поєднанні з фінансовою підтримкою допоможе їй досягти мети, збільшити власні прибутки та зробити свій бізнес успішним.

loans.use: To open a new vending facility

loans.name: Saboat

texts.en: Saboat M. is a very optimistic always-smiling person. She has three children and her husband works as a teacher. She started her own business five years ago. At that time she had a place at the open-air market and the desire to improve the conditions of work motivated her to succeed. Today her trade site is at one of the busiest closed markets in town. The turnover of her trade is very fast and she feels very lucky.  Now she doesn’t have to work under rain, snow and during very hot summers. Most of her clients are young women and she would like to expand by adding goods especially aimed for men. She will use the loan to buy additional goods and with bigger volume of goods to sell, she will ask her oldest son to help her in her work.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Robert

texts.en: I am a married man, a father of 6. I sell second-hand handbags for a living. I intend to use the loan to expand and diversify my business so as to enable me to pay school fees for my children with ease.

loans.use: I will use the money to diversify and expand my business.

loans.name: Monannisso

texts.en: Monannisso has been a trader during all her working life. When she was young she worked at a big department store. She liked her job and that’s why when the department store stopped operating she decided to conduct trading on her own. She received her first loan over a year ago. She started with 100 dollars and is anxious to increase the loan amount because she knows the more she invests, the larger will be her income. She was always sure that her goods would find its customers because she chose them herself at the wholesale market. She is sure that she has a good taste and this helps in her business a lot. Monannisso has four children and two grandchildren. She often says that all she does, she does it for them. She will use her loan for the next trip to the wholesale market at Bishkek to buy spring season outfits for women.

loans.use: Purchase of goods

loans.name: Larisa

texts.en:
Larisa is a hairdresser with 25 years of experience. Larisa is a widow with two sons. Her sons are grown up and live with their own families. Larisa lives with her mother. She loves to take care of her two grandchildren. 

She is very popular hairdresser in town but she hesitated a lot before deciding to take out a loan. The main factor for her decision to receive a loan is the upcoming season for weddings. During spring and summer time many weddings are conducted in Tajikistan. From previous years Larisa knows that there will be many brides that will come to her to make beautiful hair styles. She would like to offer them different hair styles and other products to use. She knows suppliers she worked with before and they informed her that buying products in bigger volume would be less expensive.

loans.use: Purchase of hairdressing and coloring supplies

loans.name: María

texts.en:
Mrs. G. is a teacher who, through great effort, has built a pre-school in her home in order to teach children from the community. With the loan money, she will remodel her home to improve conditions for the children and will also buy didactic materials to improve education. (blackboards, educational games, etc)

Translated from Spanish by Alison Rives, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora G. es maestra de profesión, además de dar clases, con mucho esfuerzo ha construido en su casa un preescolar donde brinda sus servicios a los niños de su comunidad. Con el crédito mejorará las instalaciones de su casa para brindar mejores condiciones a los niños que asisten y también comprará materiales didacticos que le permitan brindar una mejor enseñanza (Pizarrones, juegos educativos, etc.).

loans.use: The money will be used to remodel her home in order to provide a more comfortable environment for the children who attend her pre-school.  It will also be used to buy materials to improve education.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Nurfadilah

texts.en: Nurfadilah W. is a 25 year old mother of an 8 year old son, and a 1 year old baby boy. She makes and sells assorted fried snacks at her mother’s booth. She used to borrow money from her neighbor but she felt uncomfortable since it had to be repaid in a very short time. She wants to obtain a loan from MBK as she can repay the loan in a year.  She hopes to get a loan so she can make and sell more fried snacks to cover her living costs, as her husband is just an unskilled worker.

loans.use: To buy supplies to increase her business

loans.name: Minah

texts.en: M. is a 36 year old mother of 4 children. She sells vegetables and other foods as well as household goods such as coffee, soap, and salted fish. Her husband, Nasir, helps her everyday in their booth and buys goods to sell in the neighboring market in Sepatan. He will stand in for M. during MBK’s weekly meeting.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Tjian

texts.en: Tjian N. has lived with her children ever since she got divorced. She makes cookies and sponge cakes to order. Sometimes she even gets an order to cater for parties, such as birthday parties.  She really wants to use the loan to start regular production of her cookies and then sell them near her house to make more income. She sells each box of cookies for $1.50 to $3. She also expects to have more money for her children’s education from her business' profit.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Yanti

texts.en: Yanti is a 31 year old mother of 2 children; a 9 year old girl and a 2 year old boy. She sells instant noodles, cigarettes and ice using a table in front of her house. Her husband, Aang, is a truck driver with irregular income. He usually earns $10/week. She really hopes to earn more income for her children’s education and to expand her business.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Jamah

texts.en: Jamah is a seller of cooked foods and has been working on her business for a long time. She sells her goods by going around the village on foot, carrying a winnowing tray on her head. Her husband works in a factory outside her village. She plans to use the loan to buy more goods, so that she may earn more money to keep sending her children to school.

loans.use: Buy additional inventory for her shop

loans.name: Alei

texts.en: Alei is a married woman with three kids. Her husband fishes everyday and she helps sell the fish at the market twice a week. Alei sells about 3-4 coolers of fish and earns $300-$400 a day. Money they earn from the sale of fish is used to buy more equipment for their business and to help with the payment of their children's school fees.

loans.use: to purchase a deep freezer

loans.name: Tulipe

texts.en: Running a shop seven days a week and operating a barbeque stand is Tulipe’s line of work. She loves her work. SPBD has kindly assisted her in setting up her business.  She makes two hundred tala of profit daily. Tulipe’s income enables her to put her children in school and look after her family’s welfare both physically and spiritually. She trusts that the more she gives, the more she earns, and that everything she desires will be hers if she continues to work hard.

loans.use: The loan will be used to purchase snacks, turkey tails, chicken, mutton flap, coke, canned fish etc.  It will also help finance a home extension.

loans.name: Anamaria

texts.en: Anamaria is a forty-seven year old married woman with four children. Her husband doesn't work but two of her daughters have jobs. She joined the SPBD Programme in 2004, with $1750.00 as her last loan amount. That loan helped buy different supplies for her business, support her family and pay school fees for her two children who are still attending school. She plans to enlarge her Flea Market; therefore, she is selling lavalavas which she has printed herself, along with different handicrafts which she believes will attract a lot of interest not only from the tourists, but also from locals.

loans.use: Buy 40 rolls of Samoan lavalava.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: In Maria’s shop at Toamua you can find pork cakes, German buns and doughnuts. Her family size is really big and by having a shop she is able to satisfy their needs and wants. A hundred tala profit is made weekly and is used to buy more stock for the shop, and of course for her SPBD loan repayments. Maria also manages to save some money which she can turn to in times of great financial need.

loans.use: To purchase cement, canned fish, canned beef, sodas, gas stove, etc.

loans.name: Anava

texts.en: Anava is a successful seamstress. She hails from the village of Puleia Savaii and is married to a man from Safaatoa Uta, where they are living and which is also the location of her business. She joined SPBD Program in 2005, when her husband resigned from his job. Anava used her last loan of $1750.00 to buy one sewing machine for her business and to pay school fees for her two sons, who are still in school.

loans.use: To purchase 12 rolls of material.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en: Nora, like most women, works in a flea market. She sells her own Samoan handicrafts and clothes, plus other things like hair accessories and footwear. Her husband earns some money, and together they make a good profit in a week. This way they can improve their housing conditions and meet other family needs.

loans.use: To purchase sandals, clothes, stationary, school fees, timber, an iron roof.

loans.name: Tai

texts.en: Living near Yazaki is a blessing for Tai’s business. She makes a hundred traditional cakes, known as faapapa, a day and all of them are sold instantly by employees of the Yazaki Company. Her profit includes two hundred tala for flour and other ingredients for the cakes and three hundred tala for her loan repayments as well as income for herself and the whole family.

loans.use: To purchase flour, sugar, foil.

loans.name: Antonina

texts.en: Antonina is 29 years of age. She runs a flea market business, which sells 10-15 printed lavalavas and more than 10 Samoan bags a day. She is now looking into selling kava bowls as well. The total weekly earnings from her business is $450.00-$500.00. She sets aside $300.00 as savings to fall back on for emergencies and uses the rest to buy more materials and other handicrafts for the business.

loans.use: To purchase 10 kava bowls.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en: Running a pearl business is not an easy task for Naomi. Although she is having difficulty with her earnings she is not giving up, as she gets assistance from SPBD. The business helps her to earn money for her children’s future. She is working hard, with the help of her workers and also family support. Naomi is dependable and a successful mother, and a role model for other people who would want to be in the pearl business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase strings and pearls.

loans.name: Elisapeta

texts.en: Elisapeta is a married mother of six children, three boys and three girls. She is 52 years old. She lives with her husband and children at the village of Gagaifo. Her business is planting taro, worked by her husband five days a week leaving Sunday for rest and to recoup. She sells 3-4 bags of taro each week and gets $250-$300. This is her fifth loan, which tells how interested she is in being a member of SPBD, because without the help from the program Elisapeta could not afford to look after and support her family.

loans.use: To purchase 1 box of cramoxone.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Faalogoifo

texts.en: Faalogoifo V. is forty-eight years old, married to a farmer from the village of Faleapuna. They have 4 children, one of whom is an employee of the National Hospital of Samoa. Before joining the SPBD program two years ago they had problems with her small business. With financial assistance and guidance from the SPBD program, she used her fourth loan of $1250.00 to rebuild and reestablish her small business within her village. This has helped them as they are able to buy small things that they weren't able to buy before they rebuilt her confidence in her business, because overseas remittance was their only income.

loans.use: Buy 10 fine mats

loans.name: Thanh

texts.en: Thanh is 42 years old. With her husband, Sanh, she has 4 children, aged 12, 10, 4 and 2. Thanh’s family has only a small hut. They do not have any land and no capital. Her husband is a daily laborer and often he cannot find any work, so much depends on Thanh’s fish selling. In the past they had to resort to moneylenders who charged 60%/year. But now she can borrow from the project and their income has increased from $8/person/month to $10. She wants a $50 loan to raise pigs.

loans.use: Pig farm

loans.name: Faavevela

texts.en: Faavevela is from the village of Safune Savaii. She is married to a young business man from the village of Moataa and they have one kid. She is staying at Moataa but she joined Apia Park center at the beginning of 2005. Joining the program was very good encouragement for her business because at the center meetings all the members and the center manager discuss what, how, and where each member's business is, and discuss putting aside savings for emergencies. She believes that these center meetings instill strength and provide different ideas of things she can do with her own hands and from her own home to earn money to help support her family.

loans.use: Purchase 10 kava bowls.

loans.name: Vi

texts.en: Vi is 20 years old, married to Khong. They have 2 children, ages 5 and 2. Vi’s family has only a small hut and a little plot of 1500 square meters for growing rice. Her husband works as a day laborer but is often unemployed. They have no capital. Vi sells soya-cakes in near-by markets. Vi repaid her second loan of $50 and became free from the local moneylenders. Now she wants to borrow for another cycle of 7 months. She wants to buy soya beans in larger quantities and pay cash, thus cheaper.

loans.use: Selling soya-cakes at local markets

loans.name: Hellinda

loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.

loans.name: Nga

texts.en:
Nga's household has no land; her husband is a day laborer. They have 5 children but 2 already have stopped their studies to work and help their parents. They are extremely poor with an average income of only $4/month/person.

They need $75 to expand their coffee shop and make sure the 3 youngest children do not drop out of school.

loans.use: Expanding a coffee shop

loans.use: I will use the money to expand my business.
