The shop is located at Tulaele in the front of Meaaisi’s house, and she and her daughter take turns in its operation. It is open 7 days a week. Meaaisi lives right across the corner of where the South Pacific Games will be held at August this year, and she expects a high profit from that event. She is requesting a loan to stock her freezer with more merchandise, which will enable her sales to grow.

loans.use: To purchase goods for freezer, flour, sugar, soap, paste, snacks

loans.name: Imeleta

texts.en: Imeleta loves flowers and their scents. She also uses them to accent her fashion, like wearing flowers on her ear make her more beautiful. This is Ime’s life. Around Imeleta’s house are different flowers and different plants. These flowers are used for decorations in homes, chapels, and school buildings, or as a sign of a boy’s love for a girl. Her gift with plants is well known in her area, and she provides vases of flowers and arrangements for many customers. Imeleta is on her 5th loan and she is the President of Tulaele K.P center. These loans help her increase her sales and business.

loans.use: To purchase pots and plastic bags to for planting

loans.name: Loretta

texts.en:
Loretta is one of the hard working members in the SPBD program. She supports an extended family of nineteen people. She is paying for school fees for 11 children. She adopted her brother and his wife's four children because he and his wife are deceased.  All of these children's future is in Loretta’s hands. Loretta’s husband also died two years ago. It is difficult to cope with family commitments and school fees.

Loretta's main source of income was the small amount of money she got from selling her fine mats and  money sent from her brother overseas. So when Loretta heard about the SPBD program in her area, she wasn't ashamed to seek assistance. Loretta is on her 4th loan, and she is one of the most reliable members in the Center. Now Loretta has three years experience in her business, thanks to her successful borrowing and repaying. Her business involves weaving fine mats for faalavelave and printing designs on dresses. She is requesting another loan so she can continue to increase her business and provide more for her family.

loans.use: To purchase paint, laufala, needles, threads

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Maitua

texts.en:
Maitua’s store is located at the front of her house. Maitua’s small shop is one of the successful stores in the village. Maitua joined SPBD last year and she is on her third loan of $1250. Maitua's store is open 7 days a week from 8am-10pm, and she is a very hard worker.

Maitua is also uses her freezer for a second business selling ice cakes. She sells them to the village children and people from other areas. She is requesting a loan so she can increase her sales by increasing her stock and the amount of ice cakes she can produce.

loans.use: To purchase snacks, soft drinks, stocks for the freezer and flour and sugar

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria T.’s business is making clothes for both ladies and men. Maria’s sewing machine was funded by her first loan of $750, and she is now on her second loan of $1250. Maria works four days a week and she sews a puletasi (traditional wear) for $20, and charges $40 when she designs the garment too. She has one son who is a good business man. She is requesting a loan to purchase more sewing materials that will increase the variety of designs she can offer.

loans.use: To purchase rolls of materials, threads, needles, paint, glitter

loans.name: Rosa Elia

texts.en:
Mrs. V. P. buys used clothing in Laredo, Texas and sells it in the western markets of the city of Nuevo Laredo, Mexico. She has been doing this for about 7 years.

"I need my own transportation, so that I can sell my clothes in other markets in the area. I am asking for a loan of $1,200.00 to buy a car."

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

La señora compra la ropa usada en Laredo Texas y la vende en los tianguis del poniente de la Cd. de Nvo. Laredo, esto lo lleva haciendo aproximadamente 7 años.

"Tengo la necesidad de transportarme en un vehiculo propio, para poder vender mi ropa en diferentes colonias de la localidad, solicito un prestamo de $1,200.00 dlls para la adquisicion de un carro".

loans.use: Sale of new and used clothing. / Venta de ropa nueva y usada.

loans.name: Ella

texts.en: Ela Tillette’s shop is located in the front of her house. Ela was in America for years, but she came back to take care of her aged grandmother. She also cares for her two young kids. They are both at school, and Ela is solely responsible for them. She is on her 4th loan of $2250 and she uses her loans to purchase more stock for her successful shop. Ela’s customers are her nearby neighbors and village people. She is a very hard worker, operating her shop 7 days a week from 7:30am-10:00pm. She is requesting a loan so that she can continue to offer more products in her business.

loans.use: To purchase snacks, soaps, rinso, toothpaste, icepops, flour, sugar

loans.name: Arieta

texts.en:
Alieta’s business specializes in weaving handbags. These handbags are made of a Samoan leaf called “laufala”. These handbags have different designs that she has made. For some of her bags, she uses tapa cloth to cover the outside of the bag before she wraps it up with plastic to make sure it doesn’t get wet when it rains.

Alieta works six days a week. She uses Saturday to deliver her bags to the market. Alieta lives in her small Samoan house and she looks forward to building a small Samoan house from her income.

loans.use: To purchase plastic, paper, paint, needles and thread.

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en:
Alberta is married and has a son. Her husband's income is small which is hwy she decided to start this business, buying and selling used clothes. She started selling clothes from her home and in the local markets. It is very important for her to earn this income because this way she can invest in her son's education, to grant him a better future.

So that she can continue on with her sales, Alberta needs a loan of $550, that she will use towards the purchase of clothing, to offer her customers a wider variety and expand her business. She plans to repay the loan in a term of 5 months.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Alberta es casada y tiene un hijo, el ingreso que recibe su esposo es muy poco, por lo que ella decidió iniciar este negocio de compra y venta de ropa usada, empezó vendiendo la ropa en su casa y luego en mercados ambulantes que se ubican cerca de su casa. Para ella es muy importante recibir este ingreso porque así puede contribuir a que su hijo siga estudiando y pueda tener un mejor futuro.

Para poder continuar con sus ventas, Alberta necesita de un préstamo de $550 dólares, que destinará a la compra de ropa para poder ofrecer a sus clientes más variedad y hacer crecer su negocio, planea devolver este préstamo en un lapso de cinco meses.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise

loans.name: Lê

texts.en:
Lê's husband, Mr.Cu, incurred a brain injury during the war and is now mentally handicapped. Lê struggles to support the family, and they still have 3 children in school. 

She sells pottery, which she produces herself. The moneylender charges her 50% interest. She is requesting a loan from KIVA for $75 which will enable her to produce more pottery and repay the loan's very reasonable terms.

loans.use: Lê wants to improve her production of pottery

loans.name: Xx

texts.en: X.

loans.use: XX

loans.name: Anna Lum

texts.en:
Anna L. is one of two wives with seven children. Thoughts of the bad treatment she got from her maid, moments she and her kids felt sick and could not go to hospital for services, and internal guilt at not being able to pay for her children’s tuition is her motivation for going into business. Her immediate goal is to provide education for her children, while her long-term goal is to build a house where she can live in peace with her children.

With the help of past loans she succeeded in selling foodstuffs to her community. She is proud of having used the profit from her empowerment-credit activities to pay for two of her children’s school fees.

With a loan of $1000, she plans to increase her stock by buying cassava, yam, ibo coco-yam, and pepper in large quantities and retailing to other women who don’t have capital. She is convinced that her business will succeed because of the high demand from the population of the Bamenda urban center, her determination, empowerment skills acquired, and the peer support she is getting from her group members in GHAPE.

She plans to pay the loan off in 18 months. The first installment repayment will be made in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Trading and Farming

loans.name: Rachel Lum

texts.en:
Rachel is a mother of three, the youngest being 2 years old. She has not forgotten the pain and misery she underwent when her husband sent her away, saying that she could not bear children. Those bitter memories later became her motivation to go into business, especially when she eventually bore a child. From her two previous loans she was able to pay tuition for her children. She makes and sells fast food, puff-puffs, to her community for breakfast.

With a loan of $400, she plans to stock flour, sugar, yeast, and oil for her puff-puff business. She also wants to buy a pig to start a piggery and cocoyam and pepper seeds to cultivate. She sees her experience in the puff-puff business and the availability of a piece of land to use for cultivation at little or no cost as strengths, and the increasing population as an opportunity to explore.

She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be made on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Frying Puff-Puffs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling of Koki

loans.name: Isabella Neh

texts.en:
Isabella is a married mother of four children. Growing up as an orphan, she remembers hardship. Memories of when she became indebted and couldn’t contribute to the education of her children are reasons she advanced for joining GHAPE in 2003. Having received training in credit management, marketing techniques, leadership shills, and group dynamics, she has been able to manage successfully and repay her first three loans. She provided dresses, shoes, and bags for women and children in her community and was able to pay some of her debts.

With a loan of $800, she plans to increase her stock by buying at least two pieces of each design to meet the clothing needs of women and children in her community.

She plans to pay back her loan in 18 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Selling clothes, shoes, bags, and earrings

loans.name: Justine M.

texts.en:
Justine is a single mother of two and foster mother to her brother’s children. Having grown up in a single-parent home and having had her own children through surgery with all the risks involved, she sees her survival skills as strengths.

Trained in management, marketing techniques, and group dynamics, she has borrowed and repaid her first loan. She succeeded in selling Christmas clothes for children last December. She plans to ask for a bigger loan in the years ahead when she becomes comfortable with her skills in this trade.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to increase her stock, buying Easter and Christmas stuff in order to supply the local population. Her goal for this loan is to continue learning practical business skills, finding customers, and evaluating her marketing skills. Her longterm dream is to have her own capital and stop relying on loans.

She plans to repay this loan in 15 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due on the second month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Selling of clothes

loans.name: Valentine Ambe

texts.en:
Valentine is a monogamous married father of ten children. The overwhelming need for tuition, food, medications, and reasonable accommodation for his family is the challenge he has to deal with. He joined GHAPE in 2004 and acquired skills in piggery, marketing techniques, and management and group dynamics in training sessions organized by GHAPE. With previous loans he succeeded in providing his community with meat and manure. He used manure from his pig-farm to assist his wife to cultivate their own vegetables.

Given a loan of $400, he plans to carry out expansion by buying more pigs, feed, and sticks and nails to repair the fence, reserving money to meet the vet needs of the animals.

He plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Raising Pigs

loans.name: Salomen Sirri

texts.en:
Salomen is mother of ten children. Assisting her husband in the provision of fees, medication, clothing, and food for their family is her motivation. Having received training in marketing techniques, management, group dynamics, and basic health organized by GHAPE, she believes that she will succeed, especially as her husband who is also a member of GHAPE is supportive. She used her previous loan to provide lunch especially to bachelors in their community.

Given a loan of $300, she plans to increase her stock by buying koki-beans and palm oil, as well as seeds to start cultivating food crops. She wants to maximize the unsold manure from her husband’s piggery. Her immediate goal is to continue providing lunch to busy people and those who don’t know how to prepare koki-beans (bean paste, rich in protein). Her children will eat any leftovers as part of their dinner.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling prepared food and cultivation

loans.name: Evelyn Nchang

texts.en:
Evelyn is a single mother of two. She finds strength from misfortunes that have befallen her, including the theft of inventory worth $700 from a loan she got in 2006, and the troubles she had in marriage before deciding to actually separate. She is bent on using the opportunities including training, peer support, and on-site supervision offered by GHAPE to continuously provide basic services to her community.

With a loan of $1200, she plans to stock her store again by buying items in daily demand like Maggi cubes, soap, palm oil, rice, onions, groundnuts, razor blades, and matches. Her dream is to educate her children and construct her own house.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling of groceries

loans.name: Mary Awah

texts.en:
Mary is divorced and mother of six children with only one child attending school. Bad memories of the problems she faced in a polygamous marriage and the difficulties she encountered when her husband abandoned her are the reasons for her determination to make a go of life. She has a vision of building a house for herself and her children. With her two previous loans, she succeeded in providing her community with palm oil two days a week.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to increase her stock by buying tins of palm oil that could meet the demand in her neighborhood (at least four days a week). She also plans to buy and retail “country-nyama-njama” (a dish of green vegetables which is widely eaten), and chickens to raise for Christmas.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling palm oil and vegetables and raising chickens

loans.name: Grace Ambain

texts.en:
Grace is married with four children. Her life style suddenly changed when her mother died and her husband’s salary was reduced as a result of the economic crisis that hit Cameroon. She found great difficulties, especially financial, in raising her children.

Faced with these new challenges Grace decided to take the bull by the horns, but inadequate capital was a major handicap and her lack of courage to join GHAPE was another issue. The cost of the services offered by GHAPE seemed too good to be believed.

In 2005 Grace joined GHAPE and has succeeded in providing her community with firewood for cooking, puff-puffs for breakfast, and snacks for school kids.

Given a loan of $800, Grace plans to increase her stock by buying flour, sugar, yeast, salt, palm-oil, logs, Mbuh (the sap from palm trees consumed locally as palm wine) and beer. She plans to fry puff-puffs in the mornings and evenings during the dry season, sell Mbuh and beer in the afternoon, and firewood 24/7.

Grace plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be made in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling of puff-puffs, Mbuh, and beer

loans.name: Lydia Ngwen

texts.en:
Lydia is a single parent with four children, three girls and one boy. She is facing great challenges in taking care of her children, niece, nephews, and aunties. She is responsible for so many because of the poor health situation of her sibling and the death of her father. The smiles from her dependents give her the strength to forge ahead. With previous loans she succeeded in providing her community with Food Supplements and sweaters for newborn babies. From her profits she succeeded in providing her family with minimal basics of tuition, food, and generic medications.

Given a loan of $1000, she plans to increase her stock by buying Tianshi Products, wool, needles (different sizes), and planting seeds of yam, corn, and beans. She is confident she will succeed because of the great demand among the old and young requesting Food Supplements to maintain physical health, and warm clothing for the newborns, the future of tomorrow.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling Food-Supplements, sweaters for newborns, and cultivation of crops

loans.name: Paul Suh

texts.en:
Paul is thirty-nine years old, husband to one woman and father of four children. After being unemployed for a while, he completed an apprenticeship as an electrician and did jobs for people, but the majority refused to pay. In desperation he decided to till the soil.

He has acquired farming techniques from training workshops organized by GHAPE and sister organizations. Coupled with his experience, he has a piece of land on which he grows crops to feed his community.

With a loan of $600, he plans to buy fertilizer, a truck (2-wheeler), a water pump, 2 spades, hoes, cutlasses, and seedlings. This will definitely allow him to increase his farm out-put. The products of his labor will keep his growing community from hunger. He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Cultivating food crops

loans.name: Catherine Nsoh

texts.en:
Born in 1979, Catherine is a single mother of 3, foster mother of 8 (from her two late sisters), and grandmother of one. Tortured by the deaths of her two sisters within one year and by thoughts of how she prematurely dropped out of school, she is determined to be there for ALL her children.

Since 1998 she has received various empowerment skills in training sessions organized by GHAPE and sister organizations. She succeeded as a mobile food vendor in providing her community with snacks (e.g., fresh groundnuts, sweet yams). Her major achievement has been the payment of tuition for some of her children from her profits. Her goal is to provide education for her children. Building a house in her lifetime for herself and her children is what will make her very happy.

Given a loan of $1200, Catherine plans to diversify her business by buying a motorbike to provide taxi services to the population of Mulang and Ntagkah, which is less accessible by regular urban taxis due to the bad roads. Part of her loan will be used to enlarge her piggery, and she intends to continue with her mobile restaurant. She anticipates repaying her loan with income from her transportation business, paying fees with income from the piggery, and meeting day-to-day needs with income from her mobile restaurant activity.

She plans to pay off her loan in 24 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Buying a motorbike and pigs

loans.name: Christina Manka

texts.en:
Christina is in a monogamous marriage and mother of five children. Memories of how she dropped out of school because her father fell ill and couldn’t pay her fees, as well as the financial difficulties she and her husband are facing to meet the education and health needs of their children, motivate her to want to better her lot.

She has succeeded in repaying her five previous loans, providing her community with firewood, food-crops, meat, and manure. She used the profits principally for school requirements and medication.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to increase her stock by buying sticks, nails, and zinc to enlarge her pig fence, and yams, corn, beans, and vegetable seedlings for planting. Her long experience in this field and the ever-present demand from the urban center of Bamenda bode well for a successful investment.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Cultivating food crops and raising pigs

loans.name: Anna Nkotan

texts.en:
Anna N. is mother of four children. She draws her inspiration from great losses, especially the death of her daughter and that of her senior sister. When her husband was laid off work, she became the bread winner and responsible for their children’s education. With skills acquired in capacity-building workshops organized by GHAPE and the invaluable support offered by Groups and center members, Anna N. succeeded in providing her community with firewood, food-crops, meat and fowls for performing traditional rites.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to stock chicken feed, pig feed, piglets, and table birds. She will purchase flour, sugar, and yeast, and a frying pan (big-size). Her location is a comparative advantage in the production and sale of these commodities. She will provide snacks to the pupils from all the near-by primary schools.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Rearing animals and frying puff-puffs

loans.name: Mary Asili

texts.en:
Mary is married and mother of six children. The persistent health issues in her family are motivating her to be in business in order to meet the cost of health services. After receiving training in management, business techniques and basic health skills in sessions organized by GHAPE and sister organizations, Mary succeeded in repaying her first two loans and in providing her community with isolated food crops and palm oil.

Given a loan of $700, she plans to localize her business by providing corner-store services to her community. She plans to increase her stock of palm oil, salt, matches, Maggi cubes, kerosene, washing soap, and onions. She believes that her business will be a success because of her determination, the skills she has acquired, the support from her group members, the demand for the items she wants to sell, and the fact that there are not many people within her area providing these services.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling groceries

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is in a polygamous marriage and has seven children. Lessons learned from the death of her daughter and father within one week, and the experience of being unable to pay for a blood transfusion for a critically ill member of her family are sources of her motivation to become economically independent. With her two previous loans, she provided her community with mobile restaurant services and food crops.

Given a loan of $400, Regina plans to buy 60 liters of palm oil, 5 bags of rice, 5 piglets, and seedlings (yam, maize, groundnuts, and beans.) She also needs to pay labor costs for the clearing of her fields. Besides being in this business for more than two years, she is a good cook and people like eating her food. With her determination and her fertile piece of land, she is convinced she will succeed.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling food and growing crops and pigs

loans.name: Magdalene Anwi

texts.en:
Magdalene is married and mother of two children. The pain of prematurely dropping out of school as a result of her father’s death, the frustration of not having adequate capital to carry out business, and the privilege of receiving loans from GHAPE are her motivations and opportunities to change her family's economic status. She succeeded in repaying previous loans and providing her community, especially the students from the Government High School Mbengwi, with food.

Given a loan of $400, she plans to buy flour, oil, sugar, yeast, 4 piglets, animal feed, and wood to reinforce a fence. Her business will succeed because she is working in collaboration with her husband who has great experience in piggery, and the student population is a ready market for her puff-puff business. She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling of puff-puffs, pigs, and farming

loans.name: Immaculate Nchang

texts.en:
Born in 1979, Immaculate is a single mother of four children. The death of her mother who was helping her and her children when her husband abandoned her for another woman was very hard for her, but it has ceased being anguishing and is now a good reason motivating her to forge ahead. GHAPE loans with affordable conditions are opportunities she must maximize. With her two previous loans, she succeeded in providing her community with puff-puffs for breakfast. She also provides roasted fish in the evenings for dinner for families and friends who want to have a meal out.

With a loan of $600, she plans to buy a refrigerator, fresh fish, beans, oil, flour, salt, sugar, and firewood. The location of her business site and increased capital which will enable her to buy in bulk are factors she believes will contribute to a successful business venture.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Frying Accra beans and roasting fish

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Frying Puff-Puffs

loans.name: Patience Nchang

texts.en:
Patience is married and mother of three children. Challenged with providing the basic needs of her children and family as a whole, coupled with memories of when she once gave birth and subsequently fell sick with her baby and could not afford medical services, this borrower is determined to overcome these challenges and redesign her family situation. Profits from three previous loans contributed to payment of tuition for their children. She also succeeded in providing her community with vegetables, meat, and manure.

Given a loan of $800, she plans to buy 7 piglets, feed, meds, wood, nails, and zinc to increase the size of the pigpen, as well as 14 bags of fertilizer. Her experience in this field, the support of her family, and the available market provided by the administrative headquarters of the NW province are opportunities to explore.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Cultivation of vegetables and raising pigs

loans.name: Delvina

texts.en: Delvina runs two charcoal stores.  She has spent more than seven years in this business. Delvina is very strategic; all her stores are located at places where they fetch a good number of customers. She wants to increase the size of her two stores and open another store on an adjacent street. Her expansion plan needs funding. From her own savings, Delvina can only finance 20% of the plan. The remaining portion of the funding needs to come from lenders. Delvina is in need of USD 750 to implement her plan.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Janeth

texts.en: Janet sells charcoal. She has one assistant at her store. She fetches charcoal from local producers in the nearby villages of Chanika and Kongowe in Dar es Salaam. She has been in this business for over six years now. Charcoal is the main source of domestic fuel for most Tanzanians. Janet has realized that firewood is also marketable to those who cannot afford charcoal. She wants to add the sale of firewood as a supplementary venture. This new line of business needs additional funding. She has to employ an assistant, rent another store and buy firewood from the villages. To implement her plan she needs USD 550.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Magdalene

texts.en:
Magdalene M. is married and mother of five children. The vanished support resulting from the death of her father and the day-to-day demands of children are challenges she has to deal with. Determined to be a mother for all intents and purposes, she seized the opportunity offered by GHAPE to start income-generating activities. From her three previous loans, she succeeded in providing her community with manure and food, and her family with increased income.

Given a loan of $300, she plans to buy sticks, nails to repair her pig-fence, and seedlings for cultivation. She plans to use manure from her piggery for cultivating vegetables and plans to sell her produce at the farm-market of Alabukam hence cutting down on transportation and time.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Cultivating crops and rearing pigs

loans.name: Paul Ngang

texts.en:
DESCRIPTION
Paul is married and father of six children. The death of two of his children and the high cost of keeping children off crimes are challenges, and he has decided to nurture his children to be exemplary in society. Decaying moral especially among young people is his motivation. With her three previous loans she succeeded in providing his community with food, Take-off capital to his son, and training his children in diverse survival skills.

Given a loan of $600, he plans to increase his son’s capital, buy more pigs, sticks and nails to repair pig-fence. His son commitment in operating groceries store, his experience in piggery, praises from community are indications that he will succeed. 

He plans to pay loan in 18 months. The first installment repayment shall be on the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Cultivating crops and assisting son with start-off capital

loans.name: Sakina

texts.en: Sakina lives in Vingunguti area of Dar es Salaam.She owns a vegetable and fruits stall where she sells different fruits and vegetables.She fetch some of the fresh produce like tomatoes and spinaches from local farmers nearby her residence. She want to increase the quantity of the stock to overcome shortages .She is also planning to have cages for products attractive display and hygiene. This will make her products offering more attractive and therefore increase sales. To fulfill these requirements she is in need of USD 400 to subsidize her capital

loans.use: Improve business

loans.name: Zacharias

texts.en:
Zacharias is a father of five children. With two previous loans, he succeeded in selling second-hand clothes and rearing pigs for food for his community. The extra income he made was used for paying school fees. The available palm cones, ever increasing demand for cooking fat (palm-oil), and the lack of equipment to produce a fraction of what is needed urged him to diversify his business. Given a loan of $200, he plans to buy a locally fabricated oil-pressing machine. 

He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Manufacturing and selling palm-oil

loans.name: Yokunda

texts.en: Yokunda resides at Mtakuja in the Ilala District of  Dar es Salaam. She is married and has five children. One is in primary school,three are in secondary school and the others are in kindergarten. Yokunda owns a retail shop selling various consumable items. She has operated the shop for more than six years now. She recently realized that her profit margin has been declining due to the increased number of competitors in the area. In a plan to improve her profit margin, Yokunda has decided to add some items in her shop that her competitors do not have. She also plans to open another shop on the next street. These new strategies require additional capital. From her own savings, Yokunda cannot finance her business plan. She is in need of an additional USD 1000 to implement her plan. She expects that this strategy will enable her to earn more income to meet her family requirements and pay for school fees for her children. She has a dream of becoming a big wholeseller in her area.

loans.use: to add stock to her shop

loans.name: Grace Njeh

texts.en:
Born in 1963, Grace is married and mother of five children. Staying productively busy is her coping strategy following the death of two of her children in 2006. Equally determined to be financially secure to somehow prevent such a thing from happening in future, she is putting her experience and energy into “buyam-sellam”, i.e., buying in bulk and retailing whatever is in season.

Given a loan of $200, she plans to buy “sags & motor”, i.e., bags for transporting, especially raw food stuff, and have liquid cash to buy produce.

She plans to repay her loan in 18 months. The first installment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of loan.

loans.use: Selling of food

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en: Zainabu owns a stationery shop in Vingunguti Relini in Dar es Salaam. The shop sells general stationery (files, ball pens, marker pens, counter books, flip charts, office pins, paper clips, paper punches etc.)  She recently realized the high demand for primary and secondary school textbooks. She has also noticed that in the area where she operates there is no shop selling such items. She wants to utilize this opportunity.  To fully utilize the opportunity Zainabu is in need of USD 750 to purchase the required level of stock. This new line of business will enable her to increase her income and get an opportunity to educate her children.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Christopher Njeh

texts.en:
Christopher is married to two wives and father of five surviving children (out of seven). Thoughts that economic hardship had a hand in the death of his children is a motivation to work hard in order to increase family income.

From two previous loans he succeeded in providing electronics services (radios, calculators) to his community and in repaying the loans. Given a loan of $200, he plans to buy chemicals and parts.

He believes his business will succeed because people will not need to travel to the town of Bamenda to have these services. He also intends to cultivate vegetables which are used in every household on a daily basis.

He plans to repay his loan in 18 months. The first installment of the repayment shall be due in the fourth month from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: Gardening and Electronic repairs

loans.name: Zubeda

texts.en: Zubeda operates a telephone service center.She owns a handset mobile phone which she uses to make calls.Her main stock is mobile phone vouchers. Her service center is located in a busy area of Ilala district of Dar es Salaam.She makes calls as well as selling mobile phone vouchers.The mobile service providers are Vodacom, Tigo, Celtel and Zantel. She needs to have a right level of stock to cope with the demand from her customers. Zubeda needs USD 400 to purchase the vouchers.

loans.use: Increase stock of vouchers

loans.name: Zabibu

texts.en: Zabibu is married and has four children. She lives in the Vingunguti area in Dar es Salaam. Zabibu is self-employed and owns a shop near her residence. She is a housewife and only has a primary education. She couldn’t get move ahead with her education because her parents could not afford school expenses. After getting married, she decided to start a business. With the help of her husband, she managed to open a shop. The shop sells different consumable items but mainly food items, which have high turnover. The shop provides her with the opportunity to raise her children well. She would like to expand her business by adding additional stock to the shop. She does all this so she can meet the costs of educating her children and help her husband in raising the family. To expand her business she needs USD 550.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Sara

texts.en: Sara lives in Vingunguti area of Dar es Salaam. She is married and has three sons. Sara is in a food vending business. She has five years in this business. She plans to improve her business by adding sufficient numbers of dining tables and chairs, food serving dishes and stock of cold drinks. On usual working hours her business is normally flocked with customers in need of services. Sometimes she looses some customers due to inadequate tables and chairs. She also in need of a cupboard for keeping food serving dishes hygienically. To facilitate her plan Sara needs USD 400.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en: Prisca lives in the Vingunguti area of Dar es Salaam. She has spent over four years in the food vending business. Different from other food vendors, Prisca’s business is mobile. She produces food at home, packs the food and distributes it to the various customers she has, especially office workers.  She plans to improve her business by adding a sufficient number of food serving dishes and packaging materials. Recently she has obtained orders to serve three more offices located at City Centre, so she needs more working capital. To facilitate her plan Prisca needs USD 400.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica lives in the Kombo area of Dar es Salaam. She is married and has three children. Two are in primary school and one is in secondary school. With the help of her husband, she managed to open a grocery store four years ago. Her business is good with the exception of insufficient working capital, which is a competitive disadvantage for her. She recently realized the increased demand 
due to a new secondary school that has opened nearby. The demand is so high so that she usually runs out of stock. She needs more capital to have the right level of stock. The lack of chairs and tables within the grocery store also acts as a drawback to her business. She has to overcome these drawbacks before her competitors grab her market share. She is in need of USD 750 to facilitate her plan.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en: Jackline resides in the Vingunguti area of Dar es Salaam. She owns a shop, selling different consumable items. She has been trained in food processing and canning from the ‘Small Industries Development Organisation’ (SIDO) in Dar es Salaam. The training has helped her a lot. She makes jam, mango pickles, butter and the like, which she sells in her shop. She recently received an order from a nearby region, Morogoro, to supply the items she produces. Since she has nothing to loose, the opportunity should be utilized. What makes her sleepless is inadequate capital. She needs to have enough raw, food preserving, and packaging materials. To implement her plan she needs USD 550.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima lives in the Vingunguti Ilala District of Dar es Salaam. She is married with four children. Halima sells charcoal in a store located in her house. She has been in this business for more than ten years now. She is planning to increase the size of her charcoal store. Unfortunately, the charcoal business has been barred by the government because of environmental conservation issues. This has decreased the supply of charcoal, causing prices to rise. Limited by capital, Halima is not able to implement her plan. She needs the assistance of USD  550 from lenders to implement her plan.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 28 years old and single. She takes care of her two sisters. Her parents are dead. Their death prompted her to drop out of school and take care of her family. Cecilia owns a pharmacy selling medicine in the Vingunguti area of Dar es Salaam. The Vingunguti area is a squatter area with no proper sewage systems. Her business has a higher turnover of drugs for malaria and waterborne diseases. Her business is licenced by the local authorities. Cecilia wants to improve her business by adding to her stock of medicines. This would require additional funding of USD 550.

loans.use: to add to her stock of medicines

loans.name: Rosalba Irene

texts.en:
Rosalba is married and her husband Jorge works as a taxi driver due to the low employment rate in the country. They have a son of 20 years of age and a daughter aged 9. She started her business selling foods 15 years ago, with the goal of helping her husband and giving her daughter a good education. Their son works to finance his own studies. Rosalba sells her products from her home's garage and she owns a car that so that she can take her products on the road, allowing her to increase the demand of her products. She requests a loan in the amount of $375 for the purchase of ingredients to continue expanding her business, and make it possible for her to give her daughter the education she needs.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Linig, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosalba es casada, su esposo Jorge debido a la falta de empleo en el país trabaja como chofer de un taxi, actualmente tienen un hijo de 20 años y una niña de 9. Ella inició con su negocio de venta de comida desde hace 15 años, con el objetivo de apoyar a su esposo y para ofrecerle una buena educación a su hija, ya que su hijo mayor trabaja para financiarse sus estudios. Rosalba vende sus productos en la cochera de su casa y tiene un carrito ambulante equipado, esto la ha ayudado a incrementar un poco su demanda por lo que solicita un préstamo por la cantidad de $375 dólares para la compra de insumos necesarios en la elaboración de sus productos y continuar creciendo con su negocio y ofrecerle la educación que espera a su niña.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: Manuel

texts.en:
Manuel is married and has three young children. He began his business 25 years ago by working as a street vendor in the city of Escobedo and he wants his children to continue studying so that they can have a better future. He requires a loan of $650 to buy vegetables and fruits so that his business can continue to grow. In this way he can offer a better quality of life to his family.

The power to help this family is in your hands. Manuel needs your support. Make the decision to contribute, they will be very thankful.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Manuel es casado y tiene tres hijos menores. Él inició su negocio hace 25 años instalándose en los mercados ambulantes en el municipio de Escobedo y quiere que sus hijos continúen estudiando y puedan llegar a tener un mejor futuro. Ahora requiere de un préstamo de $650 dólares para la compra de verdura y fruta para que su negocio continúe creciendo, y de esta manera ofrecerle una mejor calidad de vida a su familia.

En tus manos está el poder ayudar a esta familia, Manuel necesita de tu apoyo, decídete a contribuir, ellos te lo agradecerán.

loans.use: To buy stock of fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Socorro

texts.en:
Socorro is divorced and has a daughter who depends on her financially. Socorro works in a restaurant making food and she began selling cosmetics 15 years ago because the wages she receives are not enough to meet the basic needs of her family. Socorro is a very hard-working woman and that is why she is requesting a loan of $550 dollars with which she plans to buy a supply of products she can offer to her clients and thereby increase her earnings.

You can contribute to the improvement of conditions in which Socorro and her daughter now live. Your help will be of great use to this family. Socorro believes strongly in the power of human warmth and goodness to help those most in need. For this reason, she is awaiting your cooperation and offers to pay the loan she is given over a period of 6 months.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Socorro es divorciada, tiene una hija que depende económicamente de ella. Socorro trabaja en un restaurante haciendo comida, y por necesidad hace 15 años inició vendiendo cosméticos, dado que la pensión que recibe es muy poca para satisfacer las necesidades básicas de su familia. Socorro es una mujer muy trabajadora y por ello es que ella solicita un crédito de $550 dólares con los que planea surtirse de mercancía para ofrecérsela a sus clientes y así aumentar sus ingresos.

Tú puedes contribuir a mejorar las condiciones en que en las que viven ahora Socorro y su hija. Tú apoyo será de gran utilidad para esta familia, ella confía mucho en la calidad humana de las personas y su bondad para ayudar a los que más necesitan por ello espera su cooperación y ofrece pagar el préstamo que le den en un período de 6 meses.

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise

loans.name: Martha Francisca

texts.en:
Martha has three children who are already married and her husband is a laborer. The income he receives is very low. For this reason, she has been selling used clothing from her home and also in the street markets near her home for the past 15 years. Martha is requesting a loan of $550 to buy an inventory of clothing for the new season with the purpose of offering a better variety to her clients, and thereby being able to improve her income.

Martha is a very enterprising woman who needs your support to be able to achieve her goals. This is the way she can get ahead, so please support her.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Martha tiene tres hijos que ya están casados, su esposo es obrero y el ingreso que recibe es muy bajo, por este motivo hace 15 años que se ha dedicado a la venta D. ropa usada, que realiza en su domicilio y en mercados ambulantes que se ubican cerca D. su hogar. Martha solicita un préstamo D. $550 dólares para surtirse D. ropa D. nueva temporada, con la finalidad D. ofrecer una mayor variedad a sus clientes y poder obtener mejores ingresos.

Martha es una mujer emprendedora que necesita D. tu apoyo para poder lograr sus metas, esta es la manera en la que ella pueD. salir adelante, apóyala.

loans.use: To buy inventory of clothing

loans.name: Claudia Verónica

texts.en:
Claudia is 42 years old, has two children of which the eldest is married and the youngest is still in school. Her husband's income is small, which is why she started selling tacos three years ago, hoping for a better quality of life and a good education for her son. She is requesting a loan in the amount of $250 for the purchase of ingredients needed for making her products.

Claudia is confident that she will soon be able to expand her business and help support her family, and extends her thanks for your generosity and your human compassion to reach out to support those that need it most.

Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Claudia tiene 42 años de edad, tiene dos hijos de los cuales la mayor es casada y el menor continua estudiando. Los ingresos que recibe su esposo son muy bajos, por lo que ella comenzó a vender tacos de vapor hace tres años, en busca de un mejor nivel de vida y una buena educación para su hijo. Ella solicita un crédito por la cantidad de $250 dólares para la compra de los insumos necesarios para la elaboración de su comida.

Claudia confía en que pronto lograra hacer crecer su negocio y apoyar a su familia, y agradece tu generosidad y calidez humana para apoyar a quien más lo necesita.

loans.use: Purchase of ingredients

loans.name: Juan Manuel

texts.en:
Juan Manuel is a hard-working and responsible man who looks after the well being of his family. Due to economic need, his wife, Lilia, works as a cook in a factory, and he is very proud of his daughter, who is studying at the university. He began working as a taxi driver three years ago when he lost his job at the company where he worked. Because of his age, it was not easy to find another job. However, he is content with his new occupation because it has allowed him to pay for his daughter’s education and it has provided for his family.

Now Juan Manuel needs a loan of $275, which he wishes to use for maintenance of his taxi and to buy new tires, with the purpose of improving his service and offering better security to his clients. You can help this family get ahead. Please support them!

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

Juan Manuel es un hombre trabajador y responsable, que busca el bienestar para su familia. Por necesidad su esposa Lilia trabaja de cocinera en una fábrica, y se enorgullece de su hija que ya estudia en la universidad. Empezó con este oficio hace tres años al ser despedido de la empresa para la que laboraba, y por su edad no le fue fácil encontrar otro trabajo. Pero se encuentra contento con su oficio porque esto le ha permitido pagar la educación de su hija y le ha dado el sustento a su familia.

Ahora Juan Manuel requiere de un préstamo de $275 dólares que desea utilizar para el mantenimiento de su taxi y comprar llantas nuevas, con la finalidad de mejorar su servicio y ofrecer más seguridad a sus clientes. Tú puedes contribuir a la superación de esta familia ¡Apóyalos!.

loans.use: Maintenance for his taxi

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.en:
María Elena is characterized by being an enterprising and enthusiastic person. She is 41 years old, she is married and has two children who are studying. Her family does not have a steady income because her husband works as a mason and work is scarce. María Elena began her business ten years ago in order to be able to contribute with something to improve the economic conditions of her family and to be able to give her children an education.

The income María Elena makes from her job is extremely important for her family and she asks for your generosity, through a loan of $250, so that she can buy the ingredients she needs to continue making the snacks she sells. You can help this family, please decide to do it.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Maria Elena se caracteriza por ser una persona emprendedora y entusiasta. Ella tiene 41 años de edad, está casada y tiene dos hijos que están estudiando. Su familia no cuenta con un ingreso fijo porque su esposo trabaja por su cuenta de albañil y el trabajo es escaso. María Elena comenzó este negocio hace diez años, para poder contribuir con algo a mejorar las condiciones de su familia y poder darles educación a sus hijos.

Para Maria Elena y su familia es fundamental el ingreso que recibe de su trabajo y pide de tu apoyo y generosidad para poder comprar los insumos que necesita para seguir elaborando los antojitos, mediante un préstamo de $250 dólares. Tú puedes ayudar a esta familia, decídete a hacerlo.

loans.use: To buy stock of food ingredients

loans.name: Georgina

texts.en: Aunt Georgina is a petty trader who is also a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has gone through the TEACH Lending program and is very much conversant with simle record keeping methods. She needs a loan amount of $750 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ma Esperanza

texts.en:
"Ms. Pearl", as she is called by her neighbors, operates a small taco stand. With her earnings, she helps her husband with the family's expenses. "I started selling tacos in 2002, using my own kitchen. Today I have a little place installed outside my house. I need this loan to buy supplies. My main job is to keep my customers satisfied. I am asking for a loan of $1,000.00."

(Translated from the Spanish by Naomi Johnson, Kiva volunteer)

Doña "Perla" como la llaman sus vecinos, cuenta con un pequeño puesto de tacos, con lo que vende apoya a su marido para los gastos de la familia. " Yo empece en el año del 2002 a vender tacos utilizando mi propia cocina, hoy en día cuento con un puesto instalado a las afueras de mi vivienda, requiero de apoyo para la compra de mercancia mi principal labor es mantener a mis clientes satisfechos solicito un prestamo de $1,000.00 dlls.

loans.use: To buy food products. / Para la compra de los productos alimenticios.

loans.name: Rosina

texts.en: Rosina, grandmother of six, uses the TEACH Lending program of Kraban Support Foundation. She manages her business using basic bookkeeping techniques. She requires a loan of $650 to help her stay in business and expand.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Matilda

texts.en: As a charcoal seller, Auntie Mat is still working to support her family. She is among the clientele of Kraban Support Foundation and has been trained using the TEACH Lending program.She is well vested in proper record keeping. She needs a loan of $800 to expand her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Madame Esther sells foodstuffs and vegetables. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has gone through the TEACH Lending program and knows how to keep accounts for her business. She needs a loan of $650 to expand her business.

loans.use: Woking capital

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is a retailer who buys and sells cereals. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has been trained in the TEACH Lending program. She also has practical knowledge in record keeping. Janet needs a loan of $700 to help improve her business and her life.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: "I want to be able to expand my business, make more money, and send my children to school." This was what Madame Elizabeth said when she was asked why she needed a loan. She knows what this entails from training with the TEACH Lending progam of Kraban Support Foundation. She has training in bookkeeping and needs a loan of $650 to expand her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Margerete

texts.en: Maggie is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has been educated in the TEACH Lending program. She also has book-keeping skills. She needs a loan of $700 to keep her operating the business and making provisions for expansion.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Maggie is 36 years old and mother of 2 children. She completed only her basic education and went into trade. Later she decided to concentrate on the sale of charcoal. She has been in this business over the last 5 years. She wants the KIVA loan to stock up well in advance before the rains begin in May. This would help her to meet her customers' needs during the wet season.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Vicky is 28 years old and a mother of 2. She deals in the sale of cereals in front of the family house. She acquires her supplies on credit from the wholesalers thus decreasing the range of her anticipated profit. Her objective of sourcing the KIVA loan is to enable her to purchase the items in sacks and pay upfront. This she believes would give her an advantage in the re-sale of the items. They include maize, beans, groundnuts, and millet.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kweku

texts.en: Kweku is 49 years old and father of 5 children who are all in school. He has run an elecrical shop in his community for the past 10 years. Having participated in the TEACH sessions of KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION in October, 2006, he decided to join the KIVA program by seeking a loan. He intends to use the loan to buy more stock for his shop. This will enable him to undertake some repair work in clients' houses and work directly on their appliances which will lead to increased income levels.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a young man of 19. He has completed secondary eduction but with no support to continue at the university level. He is therefore running a general provisions store in a rented shop. He plans to continue his education in the future, however, he is seeking  KIVA assistance to augment his capital and expand the business. This would help him to save enough towards his further education.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is 42 and mother of 3 children. She sells cassava in the community market. This has been her business over the past 5 years. She procures her supplies from outlying villages and transports the supplies to the town. Since cassava is a perishable commodity, she is compelled to buy only what can be sold within, say, 3 days. However, she sees the potential to purchase more for onward sale to other retailers in the satellite markets within the town for additional profit. She plans to invest the KIVA loan in this business.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is 36 and mother of 3 children. She retails plantains in the satellite market in her community. Plantains can keep for some time and are even worth more when they ripen. Vida is seeking the KIVA assistance to enable her to buy in bulk quantities for retail and wholesale to other retailers in the market. She is a beneficiary of the TEACH sessions provided by KRABAN, which she attended in October 2006.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Kwesi

texts.en: Kwesi is 42 and father of 5 children, 4 of whom are in school at various levels. He retails household items in a rented shop in his community. With only a basic level in education, he has managed to run this business over the last 6 years. He took part in the TEACH learning sessions facilitated by KRABAN SUPPORT FOUNDATION in late 2006. He expects the KIVA loan to give a major push to his business.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Ernestina

texts.en: Ernestina is 27 years old and mother of one child. She had no education at all but has managed to learn hairdressing. She has been practising for the past 5 years in her community. A product of KRABAN'S TEACH learning ssssions, Ernestina has expressed much enthusiasm for using the KIVA loan assistance to improve her services to the numerous clients who patronise the shop.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Philomina

texts.en: Mina is a young woman of 22 with no children. She has taken over the running of her mother's local food joint. She prepares "banku," a local food made from maize, for residents in her community during the mornings and evenings. She intends to use the KIVA loan to erect a shed to serve as an eating place so that those who wish can have their meal there. This she hopes will help her retain a lot of patrons to sustain her business.

loans.use: Shed Construction

loans.name: Eva

texts.en: Eva is 48 years old and married with 5 children. She operates a little store that serves snacks to the public. She is supplied by Coca-Cola Bottling branch in Takoradi once a week. Even though she has a wide client base, her supplies are highly limited by her capital. She would therefore like to seek the KIVA loan to increase the quantity of crates she buys on weekly basis.

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Susanti

texts.en: Susanti is a 26 year old mother of two children. The eldest is 4 and the second is a baby of only 4 months. She has had a small store called “Warung” for a long time. She sells household goods like instant noodles, cigarettes, sugar and kerosene. She was funded by her husband’s money but now she requires additional working capital from MBK. She wants to have this loan to buy more goods since her husband, Saipudin, is only an unskilled worker who earns a weekly income of $15.

loans.use: Purchase stock for her store

loans.name: Yoyoh

texts.en: Yoyoh is a married woman and has one child who is 2 years old. She sells firewood which she buys near her husband’s store. She sells a bundle of firewood for $0.10. She usually earns $0.80 per day. Her buyers use the firewood for daily cooking. Her husband, Kosim, works in a material construction store.  His weekly income is $10/week. She very much wants to have the loan to buy more firewood.

loans.use: Purchase more firewood for her business

loans.name: Masnah

texts.en: Masnah is a 32 year old mother of three children. She runs her business by selling household goods such as soaps, kerosene and various fried snacks at a small shop in front of her house. Her husband, Masdupi, sells cemetery goods such as flowers, rose water, etc. He comes home every 10 days and usually earns $15/10 days.

loans.use: Capital

loans.name: Jumiati

texts.en: Jumiati is a mother of four children. She has been running her business since before she became a member of MBK. She had to sell her TV to open the grocery store because her husband does not have a fixed job. Now, her husband helps her to run the store. She also has another business which is sewing and putting beads on clothes. Her daughter helps her with it. She earns $4/day and sometimes she even gets an order to do a traditional washing service for which she earns an additional income of $3/day. She very much wants to have the loan to buy kerosene for her husband, so that he can sell it by going around the village.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Latifah

texts.en: Latifah is a 25 year old mother of one child. She used to help her husband selling kerosene and motor oil in their small garage. She needs this loan to buy more kerosene, motor oil and some snacks that she will sell from her house. Her husband, Suryadi, works as a factory labourer.

loans.use: Capital to start her business

loans.name: Santi

texts.en: Santi is a 27 year old mother of 3 children. The eldest is a boy and the younger two are girls. They are all in elementary school. She makes doormats using fabric remnants that she stitches together into nice doormats. She buys the material from garment factories nearby for $0.18/kg. She has been in this business since before she joined MBK. She sells her products for $2.50 - $3.80 per score through intermediary traders as she does not have the courage to sell them directly yet. She needs this loan so that she can buy more materials for making her products.

loans.use: Purchase materials to make her doormats

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is a 46 year old mother of 5 children. The first two are married, the third one, Maya, is already working and the last two are still in elementary school. She decided to start her own business when her husband, Jaenudin, got sick. She has a small shop which provides household goods and Indonesian salad called “gado-gado”. She heard about MBK from her friend when she was struggling to find additional working capital for her shop. After joining MBK as a member, she is now able to increase her income. She hopes to get a bigger loan to stock her shop comprehensively.

loans.use: Capital to complete her shop

loans.name: Bashorat

texts.en: Bashorat K. has 6 children. Her husband works at the big plant that produces aluminum. He is a worker. Four of their children live with them in one house. They help Bashorat in her business. They bring the goods from Dushanbe central wholesale market together. Due to strong wedding traditions Bashorat needs additional resources for her elder son and daughter. In Tajikistan one of the sons stays with his parents after he gets married. They work hard because they have to expand their house for their daughter-in-law. She hopes that her son will get married this year. Her current request for a loan is for buying new season clothes. She considers spring to be a good season for her trade as weather becomes warm and people tend to buy many new things.

loans.use: Purchase spring season clothes

loans.name: Muhabbat

texts.en: Muhabbat has over 8 years of experience in her business. She works at central open-air market. She lives in the same house with her family, parents-in-law and brother-in law. Muhabbat has three children. They all go to secondary school. Her husband is a worker in an aluminum plant. Her dream is for her older son to get a University degree and become an engineer in the aluminum plant and for her daughter to be an interpreter. So she tries her best to support them  to get high quality educations. Her current request is for purchasing new season goods from the wholesale market. She makes a trip to this market twice a week. If she had more money she would buy goods in a bigger volume and wouldn't have to make these trips so often. Even though the wholesale market is not far away Muhabbat still has high transportation expenses.

loans.use: Purchase spring season clothes

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
Dilorom is 21 years old. She is engaged in trading of seeds of various plants and vegetables. Her hobby is to grow flowers and garden products, so it is very easy for her to interact with her clients and give advice. At the current time she works at the market but her goal is open her own shop where she could sell different kinds of seeds, spices and flowers. She has seen very beautiful flower shops in foreign movies and she thinks she could manage a shop like that. Currently there is no such shop in her town and since she already has many regular clients she is sure her shop will be a success. 
Another dream that she has is to study at biology  in the University. But her parents do not have enough money to pay for her education. Dilorom has three brothers and two sisters.
She will use her loan to rent the premises and repair it for her future shop and she will save the profit for her future education.

loans.use: Rent and repairs of the shop

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Sakhlo

texts.en: Shakhlo is one of our first clients in the south of Tajikistan.  Shakhlo lives with her parents. She has one sister and two brothers. She helps her parents financially working in the market. She has been working at the market for over three years.  She likes the interaction with people. Her goal is  to purchase her own flat and to  prepare for her future family. She would like to expand her activity and to involve in her business her boyfriend who left for Russia to work ata construction site. They would like to get married this summer and need to arrange several issues regarding the wedding and their own house. Shaakhlo will use her loan to increase the assortment of goods that she sells. She would like to sell women’s underwear as well.

loans.use: Add new line of goods

loans.name: Malohat

texts.en: Malohat was a housewife since she got married 15 years ago. She has three children and all three study in secondary school. She decided to start working only after her kids were grown up enough to be more or less independent. She learned the basics of the trade from her best friend. She sells womens clothing and shoes at the market. She rents a small space in one of the market shops. Her best friend has been traveling to the wholesale market in Bishkek for the last three years and she is the one who was bringing Malohat goods to sell. Of course Malohat realized that if she went to wholesale market herself she would get higher profit from goods that she sells but she never had enough money to buy a large number of goods. This will not be the first loan that she has received. Malohat has been aclient of MicroInvest for over one year. She never had difficulties repaying her loans and she is sure that will repay this loan successfully.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Kurbonjon

texts.en: Kurbonjon has 6 years of experience in trade. She is married and has two sons. The whole family lives with her parents-in-law. They were the ones who suggested to Kurbonjon to start her own business. They assured her that they will take care of thechildren while she is at work. Her husband works as a driver in a big company producing jeans. Currently Kurbonjon works on her own and after receiving the loan she would like to open one more location for trade. She will hire an employee to help her with that. This second location will be placed at the big open-air market on Fridays and Sundays. She has already chosen the place and submitted the necessary documents to the market administration for it. She has to pay $30 per month as rent  for this place and the rest of the money she will spend to buy goods.

loans.use: Opening a second location for trade

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en: Back in September 2003 Rustam had a very limited assortement of goods. He worked in an open-air market every day and made about $30 per month. His goal was to improve working conditions and to increase the number and variety of goods. He received his first loan - $100, gradually developed his business and step by step increased his loan amount.  He rented another trade site located near his current place and he is managing both places himself. As he continued his cooperation with MicroInvest and he also improved the quality of sold goods and obtained constant clients. He brings his goods from Uzbekistan and Kyrgystan. Since 2003 his profit has increased 5 times and he thinks the loans he has received have had a very positive effect on his business. As a result, Rustam also has improved the living conditions of his family: wife and two children. The new loan will be used for building shelves. This way he can use his business location more effectively and present more goods to sell.

loans.use: Building shelves for goods to be sold

payments.comment: This is a correction of a previous payment posted in error.

loans.name: Tuti

texts.en: Tuti has been receiving loans from MicroInvest since 2003. She has organized a group of women-her colleagues- and they co-guarantee the loan repayments of each other. They have been working together at the market for over 10 years now. Thanks to Tuti’s organization skills, this group has never had difficulties with repayment. Tuti often recommends other entrepreneurs in this market to receive loans from MicroInvest. She uses her own example as a successful operation. Tuti in engaged in retail trade of teenagers’ and children clothes.  Her husband Bozorboi helps her in her business. They both make about $100 per month.  They use the profit for family expenses and the money that is left, for repairs of their house.  Currently she buys her goods at wholesale market locally but she would like to make a trip to bigger city nearby to buy the goods at cheaper price and choose from bigger variety. She will use her next loan for this trip.

loans.use: Trip to wholesale market

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida T. is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and manages her business with proper  record keeping. She has been trained in the TEACH Lending program. She needs a loan of $650 to inject into her business.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy a spinner to expand her wool spinning business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her wool spinning business

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Getting a loan of $700 will help Sister Doris to buy more cereals and grains to sell. Sister Doris is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has been taught about the TEACH Lending program. she is also very good at keeping records of her business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more stock and equipment in order to expand her spinning business

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Aunty Grace is an ambitious woman who wants to live above the poverty level. She sells second hand clothing so that she can support herself and her family. She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation. She has been trained in book-keeping and also in the TEACH Lending program. A loan of $650 will help her expand her business and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to expand her used clothing business

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Asked why she wanted a Kiva loan, Mrs N. N. answered, amid tears, "I want to help my husband send my children to school."  She is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has been oriented in the TEACH lending program. She also knows book-keeping. She needs a loan of $825 to keep her in active business.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Dora

texts.en: Kraban Support Foundation has trained Dora and others in the TEACH Lending program. She has also been trained in record-keeping. Dora needs a loan of $900 to expand her business by buying tools to establish a tie-and-dye section so as to sell at a cheaper cost.

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Veronica

texts.en: Vero is a client of Kraban Support Foundation and has gone through the TEACH Lending program. She has also been trained in record-keeping. Vero needs a loan of $850 to expand her business.
